	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Back-End Developer Handbook</title>
		<link>http://utopia.quantimodo.com/employee/back-end/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 06 Nov 2013 21:25:20 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[mike_sinn]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://quantimo.do/?page_id=2680</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1> Back-End Developer Handbook</h1>
<h2></h2>
<h2 style="padding-left: 30px;">How to get API running locally:</h2>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1LMnFW_GVaRrmxRAamDnvP1THKtZ4FiP6NA4IcSte95Y/edit?usp=sharing">https://docs.google.com/document/d/1LMnFW_GVaRrmxRAamDnvP1THKtZ4FiP6NA4IcSte95Y/edit?usp=sharing</a></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"></p>

<h2 id="magicdomid2" style="padding-left: 30px;">Add credentials for test connectors here:</h2>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/quantimo.do/document/d/1gni_Z1vSxymidwRLpl5xm4c2PV0aLRexLvDn6UCKJPo/edit#heading=h.lmn9omiww8bb" target="_blank" rel="eplinks_hrefhttps://docs.google.com/a/quantimo.do/document/d/1gni_Z1vSxymidwRLpl5xm4c2PV0aLRexLvDn6UCKJPo/edit#heading=h.lmn9omiww8bb">https://docs.google.com/a/quantimo.do/document/d/1gni_Z1vSxymidwRLpl5xm4c2PV0aLRexLvDn6UCKJPo/edit#heading=h.lmn9omiww8bb</a></p>

<div id="magicdomid3"></div>
<h2 id="magicdomid5" style="padding-left: 30px;">Here is the link for all our APIs secrets and keys:</h2>
<div id="magicdomid6" style="padding-left: 60px;"><a href="https://github.com/mikepsinn/Quantimodo/blob/master/data_providers.txt" target="_blank" rel="eplinks_hrefhttps://github.com/mikepsinn/Quantimodo/blob/master/data_providers.txt">https://github.com/mikepsinn/Quantimodo</a><a href="https://github.com/mikepsinn/Quantimodo-Back-End/blob/master/old/data_providers.txt" target="_blank" rel="eplinks_hrefhttps://github.com/mikepsinn/Quantimodo-Back-End/blob/master/old/data_providers.txt">-Back-End/blob/master/old</a><a href="https://github.com/mikepsinn/Quantimodo/blob/master/data_providers.txt" target="_blank" rel="eplinks_hrefhttps://github.com/mikepsinn/Quantimodo/blob/master/data_providers.txt">/data_providers.txt</a></div>
<div id="magicdomid7"></div>
<h2 id="magicdomid8" style="padding-left: 30px;">If some key has to be changed, be sure to note it this google document:</h2>
<div style="padding-left: 60px;"><a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1gni_Z1vSxymidwRLpl5xm4c2PV0aLRexLvDn6UCKJPo/edit" target="_blank" rel="eplinks_hrefhttps://docs.google.com/document/d/1gni_Z1vSxymidwRLpl5xm4c2PV0aLRexLvDn6UCKJPo/edit">Connectors - Google Drive</a></div>
<div></div>
<div></div>
<h2>Quantimodo v4.1 Database Schema</h2>
<a href="https://quantimo.do/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/quantimodo-v4.1-database-tables-relationships-mapping-fields-db-schema-2.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-2685" alt="quantimodo v4.1 database tables relationships mapping fields db schema 2" src="https://quantimo.do/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/quantimodo-v4.1-database-tables-relationships-mapping-fields-db-schema-2.jpg" width="790" height="311" /></a>

&nbsp;

&nbsp;
<h2>Quantimodo v4.0 Database Schema</h2>
&nbsp;

<a href="https://quantimo.do/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/quantimodo-v4.0-database-tables-relationships-mapping-fields-db-schema.png"><img class="alignnone size-large wp-image-2684" alt="quantimodo v4.0 database tables relationships mapping fields db schema" src="https://quantimo.do/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/quantimodo-v4.0-database-tables-relationships-mapping-fields-db-schema-1024x450.png" width="960" height="421" /></a>

&nbsp;
<h2>Quantimodo V3 Database Schema</h2>
<a href="https://quantimo.do/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/quantimodo-database-tables-relationships-mapping-fields-db-schema-2.png"><img class="alignnone size-large wp-image-2682" alt="quantimodo v3 database tables relationships mapping fields db schema 2" src="https://quantimo.do/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/quantimodo-database-tables-relationships-mapping-fields-db-schema-2-1024x876.png" width="960" height="821" /></a>

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

MySQL Tables

fluxtream Tables
Quantimodo Tables
Wordpress User Mapping
Connector Update Count (not used)

fluxtream Tables

Address

(not used - it’s empty)

CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS `Address` (
`id` bigint(20) NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT,
`address` varchar(255) DEFAULT NULL,
`guestId` bigint(20) NOT NULL,
`jsonStorage` longtext,
`latitude` double NOT NULL,
`longitude` double NOT NULL,
`radius` double NOT NULL,
`since` bigint(20) NOT NULL,
`type` varchar(255) DEFAULT NULL,
`until` bigint(20) NOT NULL,
PRIMARY KEY (`id`)
) ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8 ;

ApiKey (modified)

It tracks which connector (see Connector table) is being used by whom.

Quantimodo added two fields, enabled and hourlyUpdateInterval.

CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS `ApiKey` (
`id` bigint(20) NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT,
`api` int(11) NOT NULL,
`guestId` bigint(20) NOT NULL,
`enabled` bit(1) DEFAULT NULL,
`hourlyUpdateInterval` int(11) DEFAULT NULL,
PRIMARY KEY (`id`),
KEY `api_index` (`api`),
KEY `guestId_index` (`guestId`),
KEY `enabled` (`enabled`),
KEY `hours_update_interval` (`hourlyUpdateInterval`)
) ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8 ;

Connector

Quantimodo Tables

Wordpress User Mapping

It maps Wordpress user ID to fluxtream guest ID, or user IDs on potentially other web services, e.g. Singly account ID, or any OAuth access token (?) that identifies a user.

CREATE TABLE `qm_user` (
`wpUserID` varchar(255) COLLATE utf8_bin NOT NULL,
`provider` varchar(255) COLLATE utf8_bin NOT NULL,
`providerSpecificID` varchar(255) COLLATE utf8_bin NOT NULL,
UNIQUE KEY `uniqueness` (`wpUserID`,`provider`,`providerSpecificID`),
KEY `wpUserId` (`wpUserID`)
) ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8 COLLATE=utf8_bin;

Connector Update Count (not used)

It was for the task, Temporary Data Cleanup. Also, Temporary Data Cleanup · Issue #206 · mikepsinn/Quantimodo. The task was canceled, and the table is not being used.

CREATE TABLE `Guest_Connector_Relationship` (
`id` bigint(20) NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT,
`api` int(11) NOT NULL,
`guestId` bigint(20) NOT NULL,
`count` int(11) NOT NULL,
PRIMARY KEY (`id`),
KEY `guestId` (`guestId`),
KEY `api` (`api`)
) ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8 COMMENT='Counts ApiUpdates. See github issue #206';

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1BfEyaw-TgvEylc6-oBl-Ncoa-fOFTmCXOdvMJpFPnjg/edit?usp=sharing

&nbsp;
<p dir="ltr">Running QuantiModo Locally</p>
<p dir="ltr">For employees, volunteers or those otherwise involved in developing QuantiModo</p>
&nbsp;
<p dir="ltr">Table of Contents</p>
<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/quantimo.do/document/d/1LMnFW_GVaRrmxRAamDnvP1THKtZ4FiP6NA4IcSte95Y/edit#heading=h.40yx6sk75uy0">Requirements</a></p>
<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/quantimo.do/document/d/1LMnFW_GVaRrmxRAamDnvP1THKtZ4FiP6NA4IcSte95Y/edit#heading=h.kue0w4op7lqq">Recommended software (Windows)</a></p>
<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/quantimo.do/document/d/1LMnFW_GVaRrmxRAamDnvP1THKtZ4FiP6NA4IcSte95Y/edit#heading=h.c1w2hpb44xmp">Configuration</a></p>
<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/quantimo.do/document/d/1LMnFW_GVaRrmxRAamDnvP1THKtZ4FiP6NA4IcSte95Y/edit#heading=h.r0jxpaopbmt9">Windows</a></p>
<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/quantimo.do/document/d/1LMnFW_GVaRrmxRAamDnvP1THKtZ4FiP6NA4IcSte95Y/edit#heading=h.j4g6lwxjheop">Server/software configuration</a></p>
<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/quantimo.do/document/d/1LMnFW_GVaRrmxRAamDnvP1THKtZ4FiP6NA4IcSte95Y/edit#heading=h.f6qn2avfjegb">Basic configuration</a></p>
<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/quantimo.do/document/d/1LMnFW_GVaRrmxRAamDnvP1THKtZ4FiP6NA4IcSte95Y/edit#heading=h.h876ac419176">WordPress</a></p>
<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/quantimo.do/document/d/1LMnFW_GVaRrmxRAamDnvP1THKtZ4FiP6NA4IcSte95Y/edit#heading=h.w23je9oxmbrw">Create a database</a></p>
<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/quantimo.do/document/d/1LMnFW_GVaRrmxRAamDnvP1THKtZ4FiP6NA4IcSte95Y/edit#heading=h.t1f3j2yiahiq">Configuration</a></p>
<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/quantimo.do/document/d/1LMnFW_GVaRrmxRAamDnvP1THKtZ4FiP6NA4IcSte95Y/edit#heading=h.wz62ki9bc7hr">Importing QuantiModo pages</a></p>
<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/quantimo.do/document/d/1LMnFW_GVaRrmxRAamDnvP1THKtZ4FiP6NA4IcSte95Y/edit#heading=h.n5cr3dlbhytw">API</a></p>
<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/quantimo.do/document/d/1LMnFW_GVaRrmxRAamDnvP1THKtZ4FiP6NA4IcSte95Y/edit#heading=h.8kjey9h6wu5q">Configuration</a></p>
&nbsp;
<h1 dir="ltr"></h1>
<h1 dir="ltr">Requirements</h1>
&nbsp;
<p dir="ltr">Even though you’ll be able to host QuantiModo on a wide variety of servers we recommend you use Apache and MySQL. Both are well tested and proven stable, and more importantly, they’re very easy to get running. If you have an existing server running you can skip the next chapter dedicated to installing the servers and part of the server configuration. However, if you run into any problems I highly recommend you start from scratch.</p>
&nbsp;
<p dir="ltr">You’ll need the following to be able to work on the front end of QuantiModo:</p>

<ol>
	<li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr">Apache.</p>
</li>
	<li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr">MySQL.</p>
</li>
	<li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr">A copy of WordPress.</p>
</li>
	<li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr">A copy of Metrolium-QM, our WordPress theme.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p dir="ltr">WordPress, the theme and related configuration are under version control <a href="https://github.com/mikepsinn/quantimodo-wordpress">here</a>.</p>
&nbsp;
<p dir="ltr">If you’re working on the QuantiModo API we highly recommend you install the front end so that you can make sure your changes are compatible with the current front end code and make changes as needed. In addition to the above you’ll need:</p>

<ol>
	<li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr">A copy of the QuantiModo API</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p dir="ltr">The API is under version control <a href="https://github.com/mikepsinn/quantimodo-api-php">here</a>.</p>
&nbsp;
<h2 dir="ltr">Recommended software (Windows)</h2>
<ul>
	<li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr"><a href="http://sourceforge.net/projects/xampp/">XAMPP PHP 5.4</a></p>
</li>
	<li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr"><a href="http://windows.github.com/">Github for Windows</a></p>
</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;
<h1 dir="ltr">Configuration</h1>
<h2 dir="ltr">Windows</h2>
<p dir="ltr">To get a quick webserver running you’ll want to download and install <a href="http://sourceforge.net/projects/xampp/">XAMPP </a>to an easily accessible path, somthing like C:/Server or the default path C:/xampp will do just fine. You don’t need all the software XAMPP lets you install, but make sure MySQL and phpMyAdmin are checked. Once XAMPP is installed you’ll be asked to open the Control Panel. The control panel lets you start the Apache and MySQL servers. If you want to have these run automatically you’ll want to <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/13605283/how-can-i-get-the-xampp-control-panel-to-install-start-services-correctly">launch the contol panel as administrator</a> and then check the boxes on the left of the screen.</p>
&nbsp;
<p dir="ltr">If you don’t have a git installation on your computer it’s recommended you use Github for Windows. It makes version control easy and provides a nice user interface as well. If you’re unfamiliar with git we recommend you read up on the subject.</p>
<p dir="ltr">Those who prefer working with the command line fear not, Github for Windows lets you use that as well.</p>
<p dir="ltr">Now that you have a way to work with git, make sure you clone the following two repositories:</p>

<ul>
	<li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://github.com/mikepsinn/quantimodo-wordpress">WordPress and front end theme</a></p>
</li>
	<li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://github.com/mikepsinn/Quantimodo-API-PHP">QuantiModo PHP API</a> (for back end programmers)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h1 dir="ltr">Server/software configuration</h1>
<h2 dir="ltr">Basic configuration</h2>
<p dir="ltr">Now that the code is on your computer we can start moving it to our web server’s htdocs directory. If you installed XAMPP in the default path it’ll be in C:/xampp/htdocs.</p>
&nbsp;
<p dir="ltr">Start by deleting the current contents of htdocs, once that’s done copy the contents of the Quantimodo WordPress repository to it. Now create a directory named api, and copy the contents of the API repository to that directory.</p>
&nbsp;
<p dir="ltr">To make the API accessble we’ll want to add a line to .htdocs</p>

<h2 dir="ltr">WordPress</h2>
<h3 dir="ltr">Create a database</h3>
<p dir="ltr">To get WordPress running we’ll have to create a database first. head to <a href="http://localhost/phpmyadmin">http://localhost/phpmyadmin</a> and click the “Databases” tab at the top of your screen. Here you can create a new database, name it “qm-wp”.</p>
<p dir="ltr">Once the database is created, head over to <a href="http://localhost">http://localhost</a>. You’ll be greeted by the WordPress configuration page. Fill out the form and click “Install WordPress” at the bottom.</p>

<h3 dir="ltr">Configuration</h3>
<p dir="ltr">After logging in head over to “Appearance -&gt; Themes” and activate the Metrolium-QM theme.</p>
<p dir="ltr">Next we’ll want to fix our permalinks and site URL. Finally, go to “Settings -&gt; Permalinks”. Choose “Post name” and save your changes again.</p>

<h3 dir="ltr">Importing QuantiModo pages</h3>
<p dir="ltr">Now it’s time to import the relevant pages and menus. A backup of the stuff you’ll need can be found <a href="http://www.sendspace.com/file/oeujap">here</a>. Importing is easy. Head to “Tools -&gt; Import” and click “WordPress” at the bottom of the list. Browse to the location of the backup and WordPress handles the rest for you.</p>
&nbsp;
<h2 dir="ltr"></h2>
<h2 dir="ltr">API</h2>
<p dir="ltr">Your WordPress installation should be up and running now. Front end developers can now start their work, if you’ll be working on the back end this next section will walk you through setting up the QuantiModo API on your own host.</p>

<h3 dir="ltr">Configuration</h3>
<p dir="ltr">The API can be configured through config.php in the APIs root directory (htdocs/api if you followed this guide). An example is provided with it as well, so start by creating a copy config.php.example named config.php. The configuration file lets you point the API to the right database, and enable memcached if you have that installed correctly. The default configuration will work out of the box if you followed our guide.</p>

<h3 dir="ltr">Importing QuantiModo data</h3>
<p dir="ltr">Create a table named quantimodo through phpMyAdmin. This table holds everything related to the QuantiModo Backend (measurements, variables, sources, etc).</p>
&nbsp;
<p dir="ltr">TODO create clean backup of QM</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2680</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-11-06 21:25:20</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2013-11-06 21:25:20</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>back-end</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>1661</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>page</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password>B1ggerstaff!</wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[3]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_page_template</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[default]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wpas_done_all</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_show_breadcrumbs</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[-1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_sidebar</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[no-sidebar]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_sidebar_position</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[left]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_titlebar_style</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[hidden]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_breadcrumbs_position</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[above]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_slider_shortcode</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_titlebar_textalign</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[left]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_show_subtitle</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[-1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_subtitle</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

			<wp:meta_key>page_options_show_titlebar_cta</wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>

		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
				<title>How to Use Github with Wordpress</title>
		<link>http://utopia.quantimodo.com/employee/github/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 07 Nov 2013 17:47:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[mike_sinn]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://quantimo.do/?page_id=2689</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-size: 13px;"> </span>

How to Use Github with WordPress
<ul>
	<li>Add your uploads directory (wp-content/uploads) directory to your <code>.gitignore</code> file.</li>
	<li>Run a web server and database server on your development system so you can test changes locally before pushing them to production.</li>
	<li>Keep your database connection settings consistent beween dev and prod, or add wp-config.php to your <code>.gitignore</code> file to prevent your development wordpress settings overwriting your production ones.</li>
	<li>Avoid updating plugins on your production system using the admin interface of Wordpress - as at best, your git copy will overwrite any plugins you update as soon as you push/checkout, at worst you'll get conflicts. Do your updates using the the admin interface on your development system, commit, push and checkout in production.</li>
	<li>Consider adding a git <code>post-receive</code> hook to checkout your updates automatically into the directory you use to publish wordpress via your web server (e.g. <code>/var/www</code>). This allows you to only check out the files themselves, avoiding any git metadata finding it's way into your web server's document root, and also means you can add any permission changes into the post-receive hook so your permissions stay consistent every time. An example is included below:
<pre><code>#!/bin/sh
unset GIT_INDEX_FILE
# the directory your web server serves wordpress from
export GIT_WORK_TREE=/var/www/example.com/
# the local directory where your remote git repository sites
export GIT_DIR=/home/git/repos/example.com.git/
# below user is for debain - you want the user and group your webserver uses
sudo git checkout -f
sudo chown -R www-data:www-data $GIT_WORK_TREE
sudo chmod -R 755 $GIT_WORK_TREE
sudo chmod 600 $GIT_WORK_TREE/wp-config.php
sudo chmod -R 775 $GIT_WORK_TREE/wp-</code></pre>
</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

Here's a good .gitignore file:
<div id="file-gitignore-LC1"># This is a template .gitignore file for git-managed WordPress projects.</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC2">#</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC3"># Fact: you don't want WordPress core files, or your server-specific</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC4"># configuration files etc., in your project's repository. You just don't.</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC5">#</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC6"># Solution: stick this file up your repository root (which it assumes is</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC7"># also the WordPress root directory) and add exceptions for any plugins,</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC8"># themes, and other directories that should be under version control.</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC9">#</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC10"># See the comments below for more info on how to add exceptions for your</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC11"># content. Or see git's documentation for more info on .gitignore files:</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC12"># http://kernel.org/pub/software/scm/git/docs/gitignore.html</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC13"></div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC14"># Ignore everything in the root except the "wp-content" directory.</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC15">/*</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC16">!.gitignore</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC17">!wp-content/</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC18"></div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC19"># Ignore everything in the "wp-content" directory, except the "plugins"</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC20"># and "themes" directories.</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC21">wp-content/*</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC22">!wp-content/plugins/</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC23">!wp-content/themes/</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC24"></div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC25"># Ignore everything in the "plugins" directory, except the plugins you</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC26"># specify (see the commented-out examples for hints on how to do this.)</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC27">wp-content/plugins/*</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC28"># !wp-content/plugins/my-single-file-plugin.php</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC29"># !wp-content/plugins/my-directory-plugin/</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC30"></div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC31"># Ignore everything in the "themes" directory, except the themes you</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC32"># specify (see the commented-out example for a hint on how to do this.)</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC33">wp-content/themes/*</div>
<div id="file-gitignore-LC34"># !wp-content/themes/my-theme/</div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Careers</title>
		<link>http://utopia.quantimodo.com/welcome-2/careers/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 07 Nov 2013 21:27:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[admin]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://quantimo.do/?page_id=2699</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 13px;">We at QuantiModo are looking for someone very familiar with PHP, MySQL and building APIs to help us perfect and refine the QuantiModo API. The ultimate goal of QuantiModo is to determine what impact personal behaviors or input variables (such as exercise, diet, sleep, medication consumption, etc.) have on mood and energy levels or output state variables. We need you to help users make the most of their recorded data.</span>

In short, we are looking for someone who:
- Is very familiar with PHP, MySQL, and REST APIs
- Knows how to use git
- Is able to discuss solutions and issues with other team-members

<span style="font-size: 13px;">Your first job is described below:</span>

<span style="font-size: 13px;">The QuantiModo API currently outputs a JSON encoded array of measurements. These measurements are recorded by the user using various life tracking applications, and are grouped over a certain time period. The screenshot below illustrates an example dataset.</span>

[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="1032"]<img alt="" src="http://i.imgur.com/BQF0aNQ.png?1" width="1032" height="448" /> Graph without Substitution for Missing Data[/caption]

For some variables (like “5 Htp” in the above figure), the absence of records for a given time period should be assumed to be a specific value. For instance, for each day without measurements for this specific requested medication variable, a value of 0 should be returned by the API, with the timestamp of that day, resulting in a graph like this.

[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="1032"]<img alt="" src="http://i.imgur.com/LU2YaZD.png" width="1032" height="448" /> Graph with substitution for missing data[/caption]

You can try out the site for yourself here: <a href="https://quantimo.do/dashboard/correlations/">https://quantimo.do/dashboard/correlations/</a>

user: quantimodo

pw: qB1ggerstaff!q

Here is our current API: <a href="https://github.com/mikepsinn/Quantimodo-API-PHP">https://github.com/mikepsinn/Quantimodo-API-PHP</a>  (email m@quantimo.do if you need to be added as a collaborator)

We're creating an API explorer here:  <a href="https://quantimo.do/api/docs/">https://quantimo.do/api/docs/</a>
<div id=":9z3.ma">
<div id=":9z3.co">We finished the API explorer stub. The admin methods aren't in there yet.</div>
</div>
<div id=":9z4.ma">
<div id=":9z4.at"></div>
<div id=":9z4.co">We're using the Slim Framework:  <a dir="ltr" href="http://www.google.com/url?q=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.slimframework.com%2F&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNFEh7feoE5abCF0sC7w5cACrtiX_Q" target="_blank" rel="nofollow noreferrer">http://www.slimframework.com/</a>  Slim maps a path to a method, and lets you insert "middleware" that in our case does authentication.  W<span style="font-size: 13px; line-height: 19px;">e use cookies for auth. We should have oAuth in the future, though. Currently, we u</span><span style="font-size: 13px; line-height: 19px;">se wordpress_logged_in cookie in the Cookie: header. </span></div>
<div><span style="font-size: 13px; line-height: 19px;">or</span></div>
</div>
<div id=":9z6.ma">
<div id=":9z6.co">After signing in, request the token from /api/user and send it in the Authorization header (digest)</div>
</div>
Here is our database schema:

<a href="http://mikesinn.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/quantimodo-v4.1-database-tables-relationships-mapping-fields-db-schema-2.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-8703" alt="Quantimodo Database Schema v4.1" src="http://mikesinn.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/quantimodo-v4.1-database-tables-relationships-mapping-fields-db-schema-2.jpg" width="790" height="311" /></a>
<div id=":7wb.co">Lots of times in self-tracking there are erroneous values. The max/min filter removes a lot of them. After this filtering, the measurements need to be grouped (i.e. summed or averaged).   Ratings like mood would be averaged. Quantities like mg of some drug would be summed.</div>
<div></div>
<div>

Initially, a call is made by the graph for measurements before a specified end time and start time, with a specific time resolution. This means that the get measurements method should be called a total of [ (endtime - starttime)/groupingwidth ] times. Each time it would add a new value to the array. The first time it would select all records with timestamps >= (starttime + i*grouping width) AND timestamp < [starttime + (i + 1)*groupingwidth] WHILE i < [ (endtime - starttime)/groupingwidth ] convert them to standard units and average or sum them. Then it would put that value in the array and increment i.
If there are no acceptable measurements within the  requested time frame, the API needs to return a user-define substitution (filling-value), if one has been specified.  If none has been specified, the API returns a NULL value.  Then we will just have a gap in the data.  For medications the substituted filling-value will usually be 0.  If you didn't record medication for that day, it probably means you didn't take it.  It is important to have zeros instead of null values, because we need the zero points to create points on our xy scatter-plot which is used to calculate correlations between input behaviors and output states.
Isn't this how we should be getting the array for the points on the scatterplot?  the get measurements method should be called a total of [ (endtime - starttime)/groupingwidth ] times. Each time it would add a new value to the array. The first time it would select all records with value*conversionfactor >= minimum AND value*conversionfactor <= maximum AND timestamps >= (starttime + i*grouping width) AND timestamp < [starttime + (i + 1)*groupingwidth] WHILE i < [ (endtime - starttime)/groupingwidth ] of there are records produced by this query, it would convert them all to si and average or sum them and put the resultant value in the array. If there are no records produced, it would add the filling-value*24hours/groupingwidth to the array.  Then it would then increment i. It would then repeat this process for the output state and put those values in the second row (y-coordinates on the scatterplot) of our 2 dimensional array.


</div>
We need to modifying our current API so that it will:
<ol>
	<li>filter out measurements for a given variable, within a specific timespan that are likely to be erroneous</li>
	<li>average/sum the measurements that are not filtered out.  If no acceptable measurements are present within the given timespan, then the API should return the "filling-value" set in the qm-variable-user-settings" table instead.  This is further illustrated in the flow chart below.</li>
</ol>
<a href="http://mikesinn.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Flow-Chart-For-Measurement-Filtering-Substitution-Prioritization-and-Grouping.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-8705" alt="Flow Chart for Measurement Grouping, Filtering, and Subsitution" src="http://mikesinn.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Flow-Chart-For-Measurement-Filtering-Substitution-Prioritization-and-Grouping.jpg" width="1270" height="2120" /></a>

&nbsp;

The interval and value (filling-value) of these generated measurements are defined by the user settings, and stored in a separate MySQL table qm-variable-user-settings.

The missing data substitution (filling) was previously implemented in java below. (Email m@quantimo.do your github username if you need to be added as a collaborator).   One notable difference is that we had the option for interpolation and averaging before. Now we will either substitute with the specified value or assume that the data is missing (return null).
<h3> JavaScript for QuantiModo v3.0 Analysis Page</h3>
<a href="https://github.com/mikepsinn/Quantimodo-Back-End/blob/1be2e55971e66df0b9e380268fa9c80251be9f99/old/qm-java/fluxtream-web/src/main/webapp/js/analysis.js">https://github.com/mikepsinn/Quantimodo-Back-End/blob/1be2e55971e66df0b9e380268fa9c80251be9f99/old/qm-java/fluxtream-web/src/main/webapp/js/analysis.js</a>
<h3>Previous Missing Data Substitution Filling Data Transfer Object</h3>
<a href="https://github.com/mikepsinn/qm-java/blob/f9b08fa95b678ce930c6dd06f963df6ab0d31f44/fluxtream-core/src/main/java/com/fluxtream/dto/FillingDto.java" target="_blank">https://github.com/mikepsinn/qm-java/blob/f9b08fa95b678ce930c6dd06f963df6ab0d31f44/fluxtream-core/src/main/java/com/fluxtream/dto/FillingDto.java</a>

<a href="https://github.com/mikepsinn/qm-java/blob/f9b08fa95b678ce930c6dd06f963df6ab0d31f44/database_updates.sql" target="_blank">https://github.com/mikepsinn/qm-java/blob/f9b08fa95b678ce930c6dd06f963df6ab0d31f44/database_updates.sql</a>
<h3>Previous Variable Data Access Object Implementation</h3>
<a href="https://github.com/mikepsinn/qm-java/blob/f9b08fa95b678ce930c6dd06f963df6ab0d31f44/fluxtream-core/src/main/java/com/fluxtream/dao/impl/VariablesDaoImpl.java" target="_blank">https://github.com/mikepsinn/qm-java/blob/f9b08fa95b678ce930c6dd06f963df6ab0d31f44/fluxtream-core/src/main/java/com/fluxtream/dao/impl/VariablesDaoImpl.java</a>

<a href="https://github.com/mikepsinn/qm-java/blob/f9b08fa95b678ce930c6dd06f963df6ab0d31f44/fluxtream-core/src/main/java/com/fluxtream/dto/VariableDto.java" target="_blank">https://github.com/mikepsinn/qm-java/blob/f9b08fa95b678ce930c6dd06f963df6ab0d31f44/fluxtream-core/src/main/java/com/fluxtream/dto/VariableDto.java</a>

<h2> Previous Variable Services Implementation In Java</h2>
<a title="Variable Services Implementation in Java" href="https://github.com/mikepsinn/qm-java/blob/f9b08fa95b678ce930c6dd06f963df6ab0d31f44/fluxtream-core/src/main/java/com/fluxtream/services/impl/VariablesServiceImpl.java" target="_blank">https://github.com/mikepsinn/qm-java/blob/f9b08fa95b678ce930c6dd06f963df6ab0d31f44/fluxtream-core/src/main/java/com/fluxtream/services/impl/VariablesServiceImpl.java</a>

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:meta_key>page_options_titlebar_cta_link</wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_show_titlebar_cta</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[-1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_subtitle</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_show_subtitle</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[-1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_breadcrumbs_position</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[above]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_slider_shortcode</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_titlebar_textalign</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[left]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_sidebar_position</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[left]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_titlebar_style</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[hidden]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_show_breadcrumbs</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[-1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wpas_done_all</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_page_template</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[default]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_sidebar</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[no-sidebar]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_post_restored_from</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:3:{s:20:"restored_revision_id";i:2704;s:16:"restored_by_user";i:210;s:13:"restored_time";i:1384018012;}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_titlebar_cta_text</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Installing Quantimodo Locally</title>
		<link>http://utopia.quantimodo.com/employee/xampp/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 08 Nov 2013 00:01:13 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[mike_sinn]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://quantimo.do/?page_id=2713</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div id="page-top">
<div id="topic">
<div id="pageText">
<div id="section_5">
<h1 dir="ltr">Running QuantiModo Locally</h1>
<h2 dir="ltr">For employees, volunteers or those otherwise involved in developing QuantiModo</h2>
<a style="font-size: 13px;" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1LMnFW_GVaRrmxRAamDnvP1THKtZ4FiP6NA4IcSte95Y/edit?usp=sharing">https://docs.google.com/document/d/1LMnFW_GVaRrmxRAamDnvP1THKtZ4FiP6NA4IcSte95Y/edit?usp=sharing</a>
<div></div>
<h2 dir="ltr">Table of Contents</h2>
<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/quantimo.do/document/d/1LMnFW_GVaRrmxRAamDnvP1THKtZ4FiP6NA4IcSte95Y/edit#heading=h.40yx6sk75uy0">Requirements</a></p>
<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/quantimo.do/document/d/1LMnFW_GVaRrmxRAamDnvP1THKtZ4FiP6NA4IcSte95Y/edit#heading=h.kue0w4op7lqq">Recommended software (Windows)</a></p>
<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/quantimo.do/document/d/1LMnFW_GVaRrmxRAamDnvP1THKtZ4FiP6NA4IcSte95Y/edit#heading=h.c1w2hpb44xmp">Configuration</a></p>
<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/quantimo.do/document/d/1LMnFW_GVaRrmxRAamDnvP1THKtZ4FiP6NA4IcSte95Y/edit#heading=h.r0jxpaopbmt9">Windows</a></p>
<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/quantimo.do/document/d/1LMnFW_GVaRrmxRAamDnvP1THKtZ4FiP6NA4IcSte95Y/edit#heading=h.j4g6lwxjheop">Server/software configuration</a></p>
<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/quantimo.do/document/d/1LMnFW_GVaRrmxRAamDnvP1THKtZ4FiP6NA4IcSte95Y/edit#heading=h.f6qn2avfjegb">Basic configuration</a></p>
<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/quantimo.do/document/d/1LMnFW_GVaRrmxRAamDnvP1THKtZ4FiP6NA4IcSte95Y/edit#heading=h.h876ac419176">WordPress</a></p>
<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/quantimo.do/document/d/1LMnFW_GVaRrmxRAamDnvP1THKtZ4FiP6NA4IcSte95Y/edit#heading=h.w23je9oxmbrw">Create a database</a></p>
<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/quantimo.do/document/d/1LMnFW_GVaRrmxRAamDnvP1THKtZ4FiP6NA4IcSte95Y/edit#heading=h.t1f3j2yiahiq">Configuration</a></p>
<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/quantimo.do/document/d/1LMnFW_GVaRrmxRAamDnvP1THKtZ4FiP6NA4IcSte95Y/edit#heading=h.wz62ki9bc7hr">Importing QuantiModo pages</a></p>
<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/quantimo.do/document/d/1LMnFW_GVaRrmxRAamDnvP1THKtZ4FiP6NA4IcSte95Y/edit#heading=h.n5cr3dlbhytw">API</a></p>
<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/quantimo.do/document/d/1LMnFW_GVaRrmxRAamDnvP1THKtZ4FiP6NA4IcSte95Y/edit#heading=h.8kjey9h6wu5q">Configuration</a></p>
&nbsp;
<h1 dir="ltr"></h1>
<h1 dir="ltr">Requirements</h1>
<p dir="ltr">Even though you’ll be able to host QuantiModo on a wide variety of servers we recommend you use Apache and MySQL. Both are well tested and proven stable, and more importantly, they’re very easy to get running. If you have an existing server running you can skip the next chapter dedicated to installing the servers and part of the server configuration. However, if you run into any problems I highly recommend you start from scratch.</p>
&nbsp;
<p dir="ltr">You’ll need the following to be able to work on the front end of QuantiModo:</p>

<ol>
	<li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr">Apache.</p>
</li>
	<li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr">MySQL.</p>
</li>
	<li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr">A copy of WordPress.</p>
</li>
	<li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr">A copy of Metrolium-QM, our WordPress theme.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p dir="ltr">WordPress, the theme and related configuration are under version control <a href="https://github.com/mikepsinn/quantimodo-wordpress">here</a>.</p>
&nbsp;
<p dir="ltr">If you’re working on the QuantiModo API we highly recommend you install the front end so that you can make sure your changes are compatible with the current front end code and make changes as needed. In addition to the above you’ll need:</p>

<ol>
	<li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr">A copy of the QuantiModo API</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p dir="ltr">The API is under version control <a href="https://github.com/mikepsinn/quantimodo-api-php">here</a>.</p>
&nbsp;
<h2 dir="ltr">Recommended software (Windows)</h2>
<ul>
	<li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr"><a href="http://sourceforge.net/projects/xampp/">XAMPP PHP 5.4</a></p>
</li>
	<li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr"><a href="http://windows.github.com/">Github for Windows</a></p>
</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;
<h1 dir="ltr">Configuration</h1>
<h2 dir="ltr">Windows</h2>
<p dir="ltr">To get a quick webserver running you’ll want to download and install <a href="http://sourceforge.net/projects/xampp/">XAMPP </a>to an easily accessible path, somthing like C:/Server or the default path C:/xampp will do just fine. You don’t need all the software XAMPP lets you install, but make sure MySQL and phpMyAdmin are checked. Once XAMPP is installed you’ll be asked to open the Control Panel. The control panel lets you start the Apache and MySQL servers. If you want to have these run automatically you’ll want to <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/13605283/how-can-i-get-the-xampp-control-panel-to-install-start-services-correctly">launch the contol panel as administrator</a> and then check the boxes on the left of the screen.</p>
&nbsp;
<div>1. <a href="http://wiki.bitnami.com/Infrastructure_Stacks/BitNami_for_XAMPP#How_do_I_download_and_install_BitNami_for_XAMPP_Stack.3f" rel="internal">How do I download and install BitNami for XAMPP Stack?</a>
2. <a href="http://wiki.bitnami.com/Infrastructure_Stacks/BitNami_for_XAMPP#Where_is_the_installation_directory.3f" rel="internal">Where is the installation directory?</a>
3. <a href="http://wiki.bitnami.com/Infrastructure_Stacks/BitNami_for_XAMPP#What_is_the_XAMPP_MySQL_password.3f" rel="internal">What is the XAMPP MySQL password?</a>
4. <a href="http://wiki.bitnami.com/Infrastructure_Stacks/BitNami_for_XAMPP#What_is_the_default_username_and_password_for_the_application.3f" rel="internal">What is the default username and password for the application?</a>
5. <a href="http://wiki.bitnami.com/Infrastructure_Stacks/BitNami_for_XAMPP#Where_are_the_application_files_installed.3f" rel="internal">Where are the application files installed?</a>
6. <a href="http://wiki.bitnami.com/Infrastructure_Stacks/BitNami_for_XAMPP#How_to_start_the_new_Manager_for_Linux_and_OS_X.3f" rel="internal">How to start the new Manager for Linux and OS X?</a>
7. <a href="http://wiki.bitnami.com/Infrastructure_Stacks/BitNami_for_XAMPP#How_to_start_with_Drush_for_Drupal.3f" rel="internal">How to start with Drush for Drupal?</a></div>
BitNami for XAMPP greatly simplifies the development of PHP applications on top of ApacheFriends XAMPP, installing WordPress, Drupal with Drush, Joomla! and many more open source applications on top of XAMPP.
<table border="1" cellspacing="1" cellpadding="1">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>IMPORTANT: BitNami for XAMPP works properly on top of the portable version. Due to application requirements, once you installed the app you can not move or rename your XAMPP directory.</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<div id="section_1">
<h4>How do I download and install BitNami for XAMPP Stack?</h4>
You can download BitNami for XAMPP modules <a title="http://bitnami.com/stack/xampp" href="http://bitnami.com/stack/xampp" target="_blank" rel="external nofollow">here</a>. It is necessary to have XAMPP already installed. It is supported XAMPP (installer or zip file) version 1.7.4 or later on Windows, version 1.8.1 or later on Linux or 1.8.2 or later on OS X.

</div>
<div id="section_2">
<h4>Where is the installation directory?</h4>
BitNami for XAMPP modules can be installed on top of <a title="http://apachefriends.org" href="http://apachefriends.org/" target="_blank" rel="external nofollow">XAMPP</a> or on top of BitNami <a title="http://bitnami.com/stack/lamp" href="http://bitnami.com/stack/lamp" target="_blank" rel="external nofollow">LAMP</a>, <a title="http://bitnami.com/stack/mamp" href="http://bitnami.com/stack/mamp" target="_blank" rel="external nofollow">MAMP</a> or <a title="http://bitnami.com/stack/wamp" href="http://bitnami.com/stack/wamp" target="_blank" rel="external nofollow">WAMP</a> stacks. In both cases you need to specify the installation directory. By default, the installation directory of XAMPP are the following:
<div>

<img alt="win_platform.png" src="http://wiki.bitnami.com/@api/deki/files/12/=win_platform.png" align="absmiddle" /> On Windows:   C:xampp

<img alt="linux_platform.png" src="http://wiki.bitnami.com/@api/deki/files/11/=linux_platform.png" align="absmiddle" /> On Linux: /opt/lampp

<img alt="mac_platform.png" src="http://wiki.bitnami.com/@api/deki/files/13/=mac_platform.png" align="absmiddle" /> On OS X:   /Applications/XAMPP

&nbsp;

<img alt="" src="http://wiki.bitnami.com/@api/deki/files/569/=xampp-installdir.png" />

</div>
</div>
<div id="section_3">
<h4>What is the XAMPP MySQL password?</h4>
BitNami for XAMPP modules require to specify the MySQL root password to create the application databases. <strong>It is important the XAMPP MySQL server should be running</strong>.

The default XAMPP MySQL password is empty. If you did not change the this password the module installer will not request it during the installation.

<img alt="" src="http://wiki.bitnami.com/@api/deki/files/570/=xampp-mysql.png" />

</div>
<div id="section_4">
<h4>What is the default username and password for the application?</h4>
The administrator credentials for the applications are configured from the installer. The default values are the following:

<strong>username</strong>: user (by default)

<strong>password</strong>: configured during the installation

<img alt="" src="http://wiki.bitnami.com/@api/deki/files/571/=xampp-login.png" />

You can access the applications directly from your browser at: <a title="http://localhost/application" href="http://localhost/application" target="_blank" rel="external nofollow">http://localhost/application</a> For example WordPress will be running at <a title="http://localhost/wordpress" href="http://localhost/wordpress" target="_blank" rel="external nofollow">http://localhost/wordpress</a>

You can also access them from the XAMPP welcome page, in the "<strong>Applications</strong>" tab:

&nbsp;

<a title="xampp-apps.png" href="http://wiki.bitnami.com/@api/deki/files/528/=xampp-apps.png" rel="internal"><img alt="xampp-apps.png" src="http://wiki.bitnami.com/@api/deki/files/528/=xampp-apps.png?size=webview" /></a>

</div>
<div id="section_5">
<h4>Where are the application files installed?</h4>
The applications are installed on top of your XAMPP directory, in the "<strong>apps</strong>" folder. All the applications are configured following the same structure:

<em>xampp_installdir</em>/apps/wordpress/htdocs:   WordPress files

xampp_installdir/apache/conf/httpd.conf: WordPress configuration file
<pre>Include "/xampp_installdir/apps/wordpress/conf/httpd-prefix.conf"</pre>
<em>xampp_installdir</em>/apps/wordpress/conf/httpd-prefix.conf (previous versions wordpress.conf):   Apache configuration file for WordPress

&nbsp;
<div>If plugins can't be installed, it's often because WordPress assumes that if it's not the owner of files, it can't change them directly, which is incorrect. Because it thinks that it can't change them directly, it wants to try via FTP.</div>
<div dir="ltr">
<div></div>
<div>To fix this, add the following line to wp-config.php:</div>
<div></div>
<div>define('FS_METHOD','direct');</div>
&nbsp;

</div>
&nbsp;

</div>
<p dir="ltr">If you don’t have a git installation on your computer it’s recommended you use Github for Windows. It makes version control easy and provides a nice user interface as well. If you’re unfamiliar with git we recommend you read up on the subject.</p>
<p dir="ltr">Those who prefer working with the command line fear not, Github for Windows lets you use that as well.</p>
<p dir="ltr">Now that you have a way to work with git, make sure you clone the following two repositories:</p>

<ul>
	<li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://github.com/mikepsinn/quantimodo-wordpress">WordPress and front end theme</a></p>
</li>
	<li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://github.com/mikepsinn/Quantimodo-API-PHP">QuantiModo PHP API</a> (for back end programmers)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<h1 dir="ltr">Server/software configuration</h1>
<h2 dir="ltr">Basic configuration</h2>
<p dir="ltr">Now that the code is on your computer we can start moving it to our web server’s htdocs directory. If you installed XAMPP in the default path it’ll be in C:/xampp/htdocs.</p>
&nbsp;
<p dir="ltr">Start by deleting the current contents of htdocs, once that’s done copy the contents of the Quantimodo WordPress repository to it. Now create a directory named api, and copy the contents of the API repository to that directory.</p>
&nbsp;
<p dir="ltr">To make the API accessble we’ll want to add a line to .htdocs</p>

<h2 dir="ltr">WordPress</h2>
<h3 dir="ltr">Create a database</h3>
<p dir="ltr">To get WordPress running we’ll have to create a database first. head to <a href="http://localhost/phpmyadmin">http://localhost/phpmyadmin</a> and click the “Databases” tab at the top of your screen. Here you can create a new database, name it “qm-wp”.</p>
<p dir="ltr">Once the database is created, head over to <a href="http://localhost">http://localhost</a>. You’ll be greeted by the WordPress configuration page. Fill out the form and click “Install WordPress” at the bottom.</p>

<h3 dir="ltr">Configuration</h3>
<p dir="ltr">After logging in head over to “Appearance -&gt; Themes” and activate the Metrolium-QM theme.</p>
<p dir="ltr">Next we’ll want to fix our permalinks and site URL. Finally, go to “Settings -&gt; Permalinks”. Choose “Post name” and save your changes again.</p>

<h3 dir="ltr">Importing QuantiModo pages</h3>
<p dir="ltr">Now it’s time to import the relevant pages and menus. A backup of the stuff you’ll need can be found <a href="http://www.sendspace.com/file/oeujap">here</a>. Importing is easy. Head to “Tools -&gt; Import” and click “WordPress” at the bottom of the list. Browse to the location of the backup and WordPress handles the rest for you.</p>
&nbsp;
<h2 dir="ltr"></h2>
<h2 dir="ltr">API</h2>
<p dir="ltr">Your WordPress installation should be up and running now. Front end developers can now start their work, if you’ll be working on the back end this next section will walk you through setting up the QuantiModo API on your own host.</p>

<h3 dir="ltr">Configuration</h3>
<p dir="ltr">The API can be configured through config.php in the APIs root directory (htdocs/api if you followed this guide). An example is provided with it as well, so start by creating a copy config.php.example named config.php. The configuration file lets you point the API to the right database, and enable memcached if you have that installed correctly. The default configuration will work out of the box if you followed our guide.</p>

<h3 dir="ltr">Importing QuantiModo data</h3>
<p dir="ltr">Create a table named quantimodo through phpMyAdmin. This table holds everything related to the QuantiModo Backend (measurements, variables, sources, etc).</p>
&nbsp;
<p dir="ltr">TODO create clean backup of QM</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_titlebar_cta_text</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_show_subtitle</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[-1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_subtitle</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_show_titlebar_cta</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[-1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wpas_done_all</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_show_breadcrumbs</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[-1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_sidebar</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[no-sidebar]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_sidebar_position</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[left]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_titlebar_style</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[hidden]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_breadcrumbs_position</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[above]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_slider_shortcode</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_titlebar_textalign</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[left]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[3]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_page_template</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[default]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Development Quick Start Guide</title>
		<link>http://utopia.quantimodo.com/employee/quick-start/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 08 Nov 2013 19:17:08 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[mike_sinn]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://quantimo.do/?page_id=2731</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>QuantiModo Development Quick Start Guide</h2>
When working on QuantiModo, you have 2 basic options:
<ol>
	<li>Perform a <a href="https://quantimo.do/employee/xampp/" target="_blank">Local Installation</a> and set up the QuantiModo <a href="https://github.com/mikepsinn/Quantimodo-API-PHP">API</a> by yourself.</li>
	<li>Use our <a href="https://dev.quantimo.do/" target="_blank">Development Server</a></li>
</ol>
<span style="font-size: 13px;">It is probably be easier to work on our development server.  Our development server (</span><a style="font-size: 13px;" href="http://dev.quantimo.do/">http://dev.quantimo.do/</a><span style="font-size: 13px;">) is an Ubuntu Linux virtual machine running on the Azure platform.</span>

The fist thing you need to do is download the latest version of the code from github. Email m@quantimo.do if cannot access any of these Github repositories:
<ul>
	<li><a href="https://github.com/mikepsinn/Quantimodo-API-PHP">https://github.com/mikepsinn/Quantimodo-API-PHP</a></li>
	<li><a href="https://github.com/mikepsinn/quantimodo-wordpress">https://github.com/mikepsinn/quantimodo-wordpress</a></li>
	<li><a href="https://github.com/mikepsinn/Quantimodo-Back-End">https://github.com/mikepsinn/Quantimodo-Back-End</a></li>
</ul>
Install the Github <a href="http://github-windows.s3.amazonaws.com/GitHubSetup.exe">client application</a>.  Clone the relevant repositories.

Download and install <b><a href="http://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/putty/download.html" target="_blank">A Windows installer for everything except PuTTYtel</a> </b>

<a href="http://katsande.com/using-puttygen-to-generate-ssh-private-public-keys" target="_blank">Generate</a> a public and private keypair with puttygen.

Install some SFTP client such as <a href="https://filezilla-project.org/download.php">Filezilla</a>. I discovered that Dreamweaver simply <a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11942653/dreamweaver-cs6-ssh-private-key-sftp-on-amazon-ec2">will not work</a> with our SFTP setup.

<span style="font-size: 13px;">Save you private key somewhere that you won't lose it and don't give it to anyone.  </span>Send one of the 3 people your public key so that they can add it to the server:
<ol>
	<li>cash@thinkbynumbers.org</li>
	<li>m@quantimo.do</li>
	<li>quipeace@gmail.com</li>
</ol>
After they have added your public key to the server, they should email you your username.

Next you can start running <span style="font-size: 13px; line-height: 19px;">Pageant.  It should have already been installed when you installed Putty.   It will put an icon of a computer wearing a hat into the System tray. It will then sit and do nothing, until you load a private key into it.</span>
<div>

<a href="http://winscp.net/eng/data/media/screenshots/pageant_tray.png"><img alt="" src="http://791840461.r.cdn77.net/data/media/screenshots/pageant_tray.png?v=6" width="332" height="276" align="middle" border="0" /></a>

If you click the Pageant icon with the right mouse button, you will see a menu. Select <em>View Keys</em> from this menu. The Pageant main window will appear. (You can also bring this window up by double-clicking on the Pageant icon.)

The Pageant window contains a list box. This shows the private keys Pageant is holding. When you start Pageant, it has no keys, so the list box will be empty. After you add one or more keys, they will show up in the list box.

To add a key to Pageant, press the <em>Add Key</em> button. Pageant will bring up a file dialog, labelled <em>Select Private Key File</em>. Find your private key file in this dialog, and press <em>Open</em>.

Now open Filezilla and go to File -&gt; Site Manager...

Here you can select SFTP as the protocol, add a dev.quantimo.do, and the username that was emailed to you as shown below:

<a href="https://quantimo.do/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Filezilla-Settings.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-2762" alt="Filezilla Settings" src="https://quantimo.do/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Filezilla-Settings.jpg" width="533" height="455" /></a>

After you connect, you should have access to the server.  Once you're connected, you want to navigate to the /var/www folder on the remote site.

api Folder - Contains the code for the QuantiModo PHP API we are using to communicate between the Wordpress front end and the Fluxtream Spring Server BackEnd

site Folder -  Contains our Wordpress site files

fluxtream Folder - Contains the code for the back end Spring Server that obtains data from other websites.

<a href="https://quantimo.do/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Navigating-to-Site-Files.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-2764" alt="Navigating to Site Files" src="https://quantimo.do/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Navigating-to-Site-Files.jpg" width="528" height="363" /></a>

The issues that currently need to be addressed with the site are located here:

<a href="https://github.com/mikepsinn/quantimodo-wordpress/issues?state=open">https://github.com/mikepsinn/quantimodo-wordpress/issues?state=open</a>

<a href="https://github.com/mikepsinn/Quantimodo-API-PHP/issues">https://github.com/mikepsinn/Quantimodo-API-PHP/issues</a>

<a href="https://github.com/mikepsinn/Quantimodo-Back-End/issues">https://github.com/mikepsinn/Quantimodo-Back-End/issues</a><span style="font-size: 13px; line-height: 19px;"> </span>

Now you can try editing the files in your local github repository.  Once you're done, you can copy the files you changed into the appropriate location on the development server with Filezilla.  Then you should be able to see your changes in effect at <a href="http://dev.quantimo.do/">http://dev.quantimo.do/</a>.

You can log in with:

username: quantimodo

password: qB1ggerstaff!q

Once you are satisfied, that the site is stable and your changes have not caused any problems, you can commit them to the main repository.

If you have any questions, please ask them in the comments of the Github issues.  Ask m@quantimo.do to invite you if you are not already a member.

&nbsp;

Though it quickly bypasses permission errors in order to get work done, the permissions for WordPress and other files should not be set to 777. This is a security risk and can cause other problems. For example, if any changes rely on the permissions being set that way, the next Jenkins build will reset the permissions and the change will no longer work.
<div></div>
<div>It's important that, if permissions errors cause the problems, that this be fixed by making a very small change that fixes that particular problem.</div>
<div></div>
<div>If any assistance with this is needed, people can contact cash@thinkbynumbers.org via google chat, and he can help.</div>
<div></div>
<div><span style="font-size: 13px; line-height: 19px;">If plugins can't be installed, it's often because</span>
<div style="display: inline !important;"> WordPress assumes that if it's not the owner of files, it can't change them directly, which is incorrect. Because it thinks that it can't change them directly, it wants to try via FTP.</div>
</div>
<div dir="ltr">
<div></div>
<div>To fix this, add the following line to wp-config.php:</div>
<div></div>
<div>define('FS_METHOD','direct');</div>
&nbsp;

</div>
</div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>How to Clone a Ubuntu Linux Virtual Machine on Azure</title>
		<link>http://utopia.quantimodo.com/employee/clone-ubuntu-linux-virtual-machine-on-azure/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 09 Nov 2013 17:42:49 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[mike_sinn]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://quantimo.do/?page_id=2739</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>How Clone a Ubuntu Linux Virtual Machine on Azure</h2>
<div id="magicdomid5"></div>
<h2 id="magicdomid6"></h2>
<h3 id="magicdomid7">Important notes</h3>
<div id="magicdomid8">
<ol>
	<li>  The original VM will not be running for about half an hour while you follow these instructions</li>
	<li>  The original VM instance will be deleted and recreated</li>
	<li>  The original VM's external IP addresses will change (you may need to update the IP addresses with your DNS provider)</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 id="magicdomid11"></h2>
<h2></h2>
<h3 id="magicdomid12">Shut down the VM properly</h3>
<div id="magicdomid13">
<ol>
	<li>  Connect to the VM via SSH</li>
	<li>    sudo poweroff</li>
	<li>  Wait five minutes to ensure that the system has adequate time to shut down properly</li>
	<li>  Go to the Azure management site</li>
	<li>    Go to "virtual machines" on the left</li>
	<li>    Click the right arrow next to the virtual machine</li>
	<li>    Scroll down to disks and write down the first part of the VHD (after http and before blob.core.windows.net)</li>
	<li>    Click "shut down" at the bottom of the page</li>
	<li>    Choose "Yes" to shut down the machine even though it will release the IP address</li>
	<li>    Wait for the virtual machine to successfully shut down</li>
</ol>
</div>
<div id="magicdomid23"></div>
<h3>Capture the VM</h3>
<div>(this will delete the instance while creating a clone image, but it won't delete the virtual hard drive)</div>
<div id="magicdomid25">
<ol>
	<li>  Go to the Azure management site</li>
	<li>    Go to "virtual machines" on the left</li>
	<li>    Click the right arrow next to the virtual machine</li>
	<li>    Click "capture" at the bottom of the page</li>
	<li>    Name the image</li>
	<li>    Check next to "I have run the Windows Azure Linux Agent on the virtual machine"</li>
	<li>    Click the check mark on the lower left of the page</li>
	<li>    Wait for the capture process to complete</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h3 id="magicdomid33"></h3>
<h3 id="magicdomid34">Recreate the original VM</h3>
<div id="magicdomid35">
<ol>
	<li>  Go to the Azure management site</li>
	<li>    Go to "virtual machines" on the left of the page</li>
	<li>    Click "new" on the lower left of the page</li>
	<li>    Choose to create a new virtual machine from the gallery</li>
	<li>    Choose my disks on the left of the page</li>
	<li>    Choose the disk that was used for the original VM</li>
	<li>    Click the right arrow on the lower right of the page</li>
	<li>    Enter the name of the original VM and choose the same size as the original VM</li>
	<li>    Click the right arrow on the lower right of the page</li>
	<li>    Change "Create a new cloud service" to the name of the old cloud service</li>
	<li>    Click the right arrow on the lower right of the page</li>
	<li>    Turn on any services that the VM provides (HTTP, HTTPS, etc)</li>
	<li>    Click the check mark on the lower right of the page</li>
</ol>
</div>
<div id="magicdomid48"></div>
<h3 id="magicdomid49">Create the new VM</h3>
<div id="magicdomid50">
<ol>
	<li>  Go to the Azure management site</li>
	<li>    Go to virtual machines on the left of the page</li>
	<li>    Click new on the lower left of the page</li>
	<li>    Choose to create a new virtual machine from the gallery</li>
	<li>    Choose my images on the left of the page</li>
	<li>    Choose the clone image you created earlier</li>
	<li>    Click the right arrow on the lower right of the page</li>
	<li>    Enter the name for the new VM</li>
	<li>    Uncheck "upload compatible SSH key for authentication"</li>
	<li>    Check "provide a password"</li>
	<li>    Enter a password</li>
	<li>    Click the right arrow on the lower right of the page</li>
	<li>    Ensure the cloud service DNS name is acceptable</li>
	<li>    Click the right arrow on the lower right of the page</li>
	<li>    Turn on any services that the VM provides (HTTP, HTTPS, etc)</li>
	<li>    Click the check mark on the lower right of the page</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 id="magicdomid66"></h2>
<h2></h2>
<h3 id="magicdomid67">Set up custom DNS</h3>
<div id="magicdomid68">
<ol>
	<li>   Go to the Azure management site</li>
	<li>    Go to virtual machines on the left of the page</li>
	<li>    Write down the name of the original VM</li>
	<li>    Click the right arrow next to the original VM</li>
	<li>    Scroll down to find the "DNS name"</li>
	<li>    Write down the DNS name under the original VM name</li>
	<li>    Scroll down to find the "public virtual IP (VIP) address"</li>
	<li>    Write down the IP address under the original VM name</li>
	<li>    Click the left arrow on the upper left of the page</li>
	<li>    Write down the name of the cloned VM</li>
	<li>    Click the right arrow next to the cloned VM</li>
	<li>    Scroll down to find the "DNS name"</li>
	<li>    Write down the DNS name under the original VM name</li>
	<li>    Scroll down to find the "public virtual IP (VIP) address"</li>
	<li>    Write down the IP address under the cloned VM name</li>
	<li>  Go to your custom DNS provider's configuration website</li>
	<li>    If you use CNAME records</li>
	<li>      The original VM should be configured properly already</li>
	<li>      Add a CNAME record for your cloned VM using the DNS name you wrote down for it earlier</li>
	<li>    If you use A records</li>
	<li>      Update the original VM's A record with the IP address you wrote down for it earlier</li>
	<li>      Add an A record for the cloned VM with the IP address you wrote down for it earlier</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 id="magicdomid90"></h2>
<h2></h2>
<h3 id="magicdomid91">Delete the user azureuser if you don't use it</h3>
<div id="magicdomid92">
<ol>
	<li>  Follow these instructions with both sites</li>
	<li>    Connect via SSH to the site</li>
	<li>      sudo deluser --remove-home azureuser</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 id="magicdomid95"></h2>
<h2></h2>
<h3 id="magicdomid96">Configure domains on the cloned VM</h3>
<div id="magicdomid97">  Ensure that the configuration files for any servers on the cloned VM use the cloned VM's domain name</div>
<div id="magicdomid98">  You may need to switch to the SSL certificates for the new domain</div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2739</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-11-09 17:42:49</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2013-11-09 17:42:49</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>clone-ubuntu-linux-virtual-machine-on-azure</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>1661</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>page</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_post_restored_from</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:3:{s:20:"restored_revision_id";i:2741;s:16:"restored_by_user";i:210;s:13:"restored_time";i:1384049321;}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_titlebar_cta_text</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_titlebar_cta_link</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_show_titlebar_cta</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[-1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_subtitle</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_show_subtitle</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[-1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_titlebar_textalign</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[left]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_slider_shortcode</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_breadcrumbs_position</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[above]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_titlebar_style</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[hidden]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_sidebar_position</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[left]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_sidebar</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[no-sidebar]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_show_breadcrumbs</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[-1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wpas_done_all</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[3]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_page_template</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[default]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Using Pageant for SSH Authentication</title>
		<link>http://utopia.quantimodo.com/employee/pageant/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 10 Nov 2013 00:10:40 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[mike_sinn]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://quantimo.do/?page_id=2757</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>Getting Started with Pageant</h2>
<div>

Before you run Pageant, you need to have a <a href="http://winscp.net/eng/docs/public_key#private">private key</a> in <code>.ppk</code> format.

When you run Pageant, it will put an icon of a computer wearing a hat into the System tray. It will then sit and do nothing, until you load a private key into it.

<a href="http://winscp.net/eng/data/media/screenshots/pageant_tray.png"><img alt="" src="http://791840461.r.cdn77.net/data/media/screenshots/pageant_tray.png?v=6" width="332" height="276" align="middle" border="0" /></a>

If you click the Pageant icon with the right mouse button, you will see a menu. Select <em>View Keys</em> from this menu. The Pageant main window will appear. (You can also bring this window up by double-clicking on the Pageant icon.)

The Pageant window contains a list box. This shows the private keys Pageant is holding. When you start Pageant, it has no keys, so the list box will be empty. After you add one or more keys, they will show up in the list box.

To add a key to Pageant, press the <em>Add Key</em> button. Pageant will bring up a file dialog, labelled <em>Select Private Key File</em>. Find your private key file in this dialog, and press <em>Open</em>.

Pageant will now load the private key. If the key is protected by a passphrase, Pageant will ask you to type the passphrase. When the key has been loaded, it will appear in the list in the Pageant window.

Now start WinSCP and open an <acronym title="Secure Shell">SSH</acronym> session to a site that accepts your key. WinSCP will notice that Pageant is running, retrieve the key automatically from Pageant, and use it to authenticate. You can now open as many WinSCP sessions as you like without having to type your passphrase again.

WinSCP can be configured <a href="http://winscp.net/eng/docs/ui_login_authentication">not to try to use Pageant</a>, but it will try by default.

When you want to shut down Pageant, click the right button on the Pageant icon in the System tray, and select <em>Exit</em> from the menu. Closing the Pageant main window does not shut down Pageant.

</div>
<h2>The Pageant Main Window</h2>
<div>

The Pageant main window appears when you left-click on the Pageant system tray icon, or alternatively right-click and select <em>View Keys</em> from the menu. You can use it to keep track of what keys are currently loaded into Pageant, and to add new ones or remove the existing keys.

<a href="http://winscp.net/eng/data/media/screenshots/pageant.png"><img alt="" src="http://791840461.r.cdn77.net/data/media/screenshots/pageant.png?v=6" width="511" height="363" align="middle" border="0" /></a>

</div>
<h3>The Key List Box</h3>
<div>

The large list box in the Pageant main window lists the private keys that are currently loaded into Pageant. The list might look something like this:
<pre>ssh1    1024 22:c3:68:3b:09:41:36:c3:39:83:91:ae:71:b2:0f:04 k1
ssh-rsa 1023 74:63:08:82:95:75:e1:7c:33:31:bb:cb:00:c0:89:8b k2</pre>
For each key, the list box will tell you:
<ul>
	<li>The type of the key. Currently, this can be <code>ssh1</code> (an <acronym title="Rivest, Shamir &amp; Adelman">RSA</acronym> key for use with the <acronym title="Secure Shell version 1">SSH-1</acronym> protocol), <code>ssh-rsa</code> (an <acronym title="Rivest, Shamir &amp; Adelman">RSA</acronym> key for use with the <acronym title="Secure Shell version 2">SSH-2</acronym>protocol), or <code>ssh-dss</code> (a <acronym title="Digital Signature Algorithm">DSA</acronym> key for use with the <acronym title="Secure Shell version 2">SSH-2</acronym> protocol).</li>
	<li>The size (in bits) of the key.</li>
	<li>The fingerprint for the public key. This should be the same fingerprint given by <a href="http://winscp.net/eng/docs/ui_puttygen">PuTTYgen</a>, and also the same fingerprint shown by remote utilities such as <code>ssh-keygen</code> when applied to your <code>authorized_keys</code> file.</li>
	<li>The comment attached to the key.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h3>The Add Key Button</h3>
<div>

To add a key to Pageant by reading it out of a local disk file, press the <em>Add Key</em> button in the Pageant main window, or alternatively right-click on the Pageant icon in the system tray and select <em>Add Key</em> from there.

Pageant will bring up a file dialog, labelled <em>Select Private Key File</em>. Find your private key file in this dialog, and press <em>Open</em>. If you want to add more than one key at once, you can select multiple files using <code>Shift</code>+click (to select several adjacent files) or <code>Ctrl</code>+click (to select non-adjacent files).

Pageant will now load the private key(s). If a key is protected by a passphrase, Pageant will ask you to type the passphrase.

This is not the only way to add a private key to Pageant. You can also add one from a remote system by using agent forwarding; see section 9.4 for details.

</div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>MediGuard</title>
		<link>http://utopia.quantimodo.com/?post_type=portfolio&#038;p=1191</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 06 Sep 2013 16:10:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[quantimodo]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://quantimodo.com/?post_type=portfolio&#038;p=1191</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://paltip.com/https:..quantimodo.com/!187eq">MediGuard</a> is a user-friendly and personalized app to help you manage your prescription and over-the-counter medications. It also helps you understand potential side effects, safety alerts and recalls, and drug interactions.

It was designed to give patients a tool to learn more about their medications and closely monitor what they take. The website provide a wealth of information that can shed light on how multiple drugs interact as well as how a drug interacts with a disease or condition. Users can set up email alerts to receive safety information about specific medications. Members can also share their experience with a medication in the form of feedback. Other users can read feedback to see what kind of side effects other patients have experienced when taking the same medications. MediGuard also gives users printable lists of the medications they are currently taking. The site lets the user search for medications alphabetically, by name or search for topics by condition. MediGuard currently boasts over 2,520,000 members in its online community.

<img alt="iPhone Screenshot 1" src="http://a5.mzstatic.com/us/r30/Purple/v4/31/b8/b9/31b8b956-a996-7f08-d7b9-4ac87565ab53/screen568x568.jpeg" />

<img alt="iPhone Screenshot 2" src="http://a1.mzstatic.com/us/r30/Purple6/v4/43/9c/43/439c43d9-3ff4-698b-7ac2-27e08adc7752/screen568x568.jpeg" />]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Tinké Fitness and Stress Sensor</title>
		<link>http://utopia.quantimodo.com/?post_type=portfolio&#038;p=1641</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 22 Sep 2013 02:13:34 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[quantimodo]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://quantimodo.com/?post_type=portfolio&#038;p=1641</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.shareasale.com/r.cfm?b=466622&amp;amp"><img alt="" src="http://www.shareasale.com/image/46402/juliannashareasalebanner.png" width="731" height="125" /></a>

<a href="http://www.shareasale.com/r.cfm?b=466622&amp;amp">Tinké </a>provides controlled breathing exercises to relax yourself and indicate your level of relaxation.  This is done by via a Zen measurement with Tinké.  Using heart rate variability as a basis, your Zen Index indicates your level of relaxation, upon completion of the 60 seconds controlled breathing exercise. Find out how relaxed you are upon completion of the controlled breathing exercise.
<div></div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1641</wp:post_id>

		<wp:post_date_gmt>2013-09-22 02:13:34</wp:post_date_gmt>

			<wp:meta_key>testimonial_content</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_show_breadcrumbs</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[-1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_titlebar_style</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[hidden]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_breadcrumbs_position</wp:meta_key>

	<item>
				<title>KeepTrack Pro</title>
		<link>http://utopia.quantimodo.com/?post_type=portfolio&#038;p=1829</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 26 Sep 2013 21:25:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[quantimodo]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://quantimodo.com/?post_type=portfolio&#038;p=1829</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div><a href="http://paltip.com/quantimodo/!7vjd">KeepTrack</a> is a utility for tracking all sorts of information about your activities from the comfort of your mobile phone. KeepTrack is multi purpose so you can track any type of information whether it is your weight, training records, pills consumption, number of coffee cups or cigarettes you had today or any other data you can come up with which requires tracking. You decide what you wish to track, how often, and what to do with the information.The information you store with KeepTrack can be viewed as graphs, statistics, charts or on a calendar allowing you to get insights about your past and make better plans for the future.</div>
<img alt="" src="http://ecx.images-amazon.com/images/I/51ekM5oKPBL.png" />

<img alt="" src="http://ecx.images-amazon.com/images/I/51ST6CWhkCL.png" />

<img alt="" src="http://ecx.images-amazon.com/images/I/61PZUF4Z-RL.png" />]]></content:encoded>
