	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Why Mental Illness Persists and How We Can Eradicate It</title>
		<link>http://utopia.quantimodo.com/eradicate-mental-illness/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 28 Sep 2013 08:55:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[quantimodo]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://quantimodo.com/?p=1985</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>Why Mental Illness Persists</h2>
<address style="padding-left: 30px;">We can put a man on the moon, but we can't make him happy. :(</address>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">How can it be that humanity has achieved the monumental technical feat of putting a man on the moon, yet we still have not found a surefire way to make him happy?  To me, the latter task seems far more important and far easier.  These are the reasons why mental illness continues to ravage our society despite the miraculous rate of technical innovation in almost every other field of human endeavor.  Each of these problems can be overcome with QuantiModo.</p>

<h2 style="padding-left: 30px;">Professional Treatment is Unaffordable</h2>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">Due to the high price of professional help, 28 million Americans are forced to bear the burden of their illnesses alone and without treatment.   The cost to see a psychiatrist generally exceeds $100 per hour.</p>

<h4 style="padding-left: 90px;">QuantiModo Would Be Free</h4>
<p style="padding-left: 120px;">QuantiModo does not charge $100 per hour. QuantiModo could provide empirical data regarding the effectiveness and dangers of specific treatments for individuals with similar symptomatological profiles. The accuracy and detail of this information would grow over time as QuantiModo would constantly be engaged in recursive analysis of new statistical data.  Ultimately, l hope to create an artificially intelligent computer therapist called Dr. Modo.  This electronic psychotherapist would engage in machine learning, continually refining its user interactions.  This would enable it to respond in a way that maximizes user happiness guided by recursive feedback algorithms.</p>

<h2 style="padding-left: 30px;">Clinical Research is Prohibitively Expensive</h2>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">It costs no less than $1 billion dollars to bring an individual drug from the extremely well-functioning brain of a pharmaceutical innovator to the tortured brain of a victim of mental illness.  Phase 3 clinical trials account for the majority of this cost.  The per patient cost of these trials generally exceeds $26,000.</p>

<h4 style="padding-left: 90px;">Crowdsourced Research via QuantiModo Would be Free</h4>
<p style="padding-left: 120px;">Millions of Americans are currently engaged in their own informal self-experimentation in an attempt to solve personal health problems.  This experimentation involves small lifestyle changes related to physical activity, social interaction, diet, sleep, medications, supplements, meditation, and cognitive behavioral therapy. Unfortunately, almost all of the data from these experiments is lost to the ages.   QuantiModo could make it easy to capture all of this precious data and facilitate <a title="Observational study" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observational_study">observational studies</a> which could reveal the currently unknown benefits of and adverse effects of countless treatments for free.</p>

<h2 style="padding-left: 30px;">Subjects in FDA Trials Are Not Representative of the Actual People Receiving Treatment</h2>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">External validity is the extent to which the results can be generalized to a population of interest. The population of interest is usually defined as the people the intervention is intended to help.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">Phase III clinical trials are designed to exclude a vast majority of the population of interest. In other words, the subjects of the drug trials are not representative of the prescribed recipients, once said drugs are approved.  One investigation found that only 14.5% of patients with major depressive disorder fulfilled eligibility requirements for enrollment in an antidepressant efficacy trial.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">As a result, the results of these trials are not generalizable to patients matching any of these criteria:</p>

<ul style="padding-left: 60px;">
	<li style="padding-left: 60px;">Suffer from multiple mental health conditions (e.g. post-traumatic stress disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, bipolar disorder, etc.)</li>
	<li style="padding-left: 60px;">Engage in drug or alcohol abuse</li>
	<li style="padding-left: 60px;">Suffer from mild depression (Hamilton Rating Scale for Depression (HAM-D) score below the specified minimum)</li>
	<li style="padding-left: 60px;">Use other psychotropic medications</li>
</ul>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">This means that FDA trials <b>do not</b> possess external validity.</p>

<h4 style="padding-left: 90px;">QuantiModo Users are the Ideal Test Subjects because they are the Actual Patients</h4>
<p style="padding-left: 120px;">In the real world, no patient can be excluded.  Even people with a history of drug or alcohol abuse, people on multiple medications, and people with multiple conditions must be treated. Only through the crowdsourcing of this research with QuantiModo, would physicians have access to the true effectiveness rates and risks for their real world patients.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 90px;">The results of QuantiModo-based studies would exhibit <b>complete and utter external validity</b> since the test subjects are identical to the population of interest.</p>

<h2 style="padding-left: 30px;">Shortage of Mental Health Professionals</h2>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">There are simply not enough psychologists and psychiatrists to meet societal demand. Almost 90 million Americans live in federally designated “Mental Health Professional Shortage Areas”.</p>

<h4 style="padding-left: 90px;">QuantiModo would be available to help anyone at any time 24/7</h4>
<p style="padding-left: 120px;">QuantiModo doesn't have a three-month waiting list. Anyone with a computer could have immediate access to mental healthcare.</p>

<h2 style="padding-left: 30px;">Publication Bias in Industry-Funded Clinical Trials</h2>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">Pharmaceutical companies that sponsor research often report only "positive" results, leaving out the non-findings or negative findings where a new drug or procedure may have proved more harmful than helpful. Selective publishing can prevent the rapid spread of beneficial treatments or interventions, but more commonly it means that bad news and failure of medical interventions go unpublished. A past analysis of clinical trials supporting new drugs approved by the FDA showed that just 43 percent of more than 900 trials on 90 new drugs ended up being published. In other words, about 60 percent of the related studies remained unpublished even five years after the FDA had approved the drugs for market. That meant physicians were prescribing the drugs and patients were taking them without full knowledge of how well the treatments worked.</p>

<h4 style="padding-left: 90px;">QuantiModo would make public ALL Research Findings</h4>
<p style="padding-left: 120px;">The effectiveness rates for any and all drugs or other medical interventions would be made immediately available to everyone, <b>regardless of outcome</b>.</p>

<h2 style="padding-left: 30px;">Lack of Motivation to Carry Out Treatment is a Primary Symptom of Depressive Illness</h2>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">It’s a rather tragic catch 22 that the only people who have a true appreciation of the pain of mental illness usually also have a fundamental impairment in areas of the brain that support motivation, energy, and hope.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">I have repeatedly learned this lesson firsthand over the last year I’ve been trying to build QuantiModo. The people who have been most passionate in their desire to help me have generally suffered from depression themselves. The fatalistic attitude inherent to depression often leaves sufferers in a state of analysis paralysis.  Instead of taking action to solve their problems, they tend to just create long lists of possible reasons why everything will go wrong.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">The fatalistic pessimism preventing the suffering from performing the systematic self-experimentation required to optimize their neurotransmitter levels is itself a result of their sub-optimal neurotransmitter levels.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">I was extremely fortunate that I had just enough motivation and resources (intellectual and fiscal) to take the necessary actions to solve my problem. However, in general <i>all the things you must do to recover from depression are made difficult by the symptoms of depression</i>. For example, you should eat well, sleep well, be active, and think realistically. Yet the typical symptoms of depression include poor appetite, insomnia, lethargy, and negative thinking.</p>

<h4 style="padding-left: 90px;">QuantiModo Will Get Up in Your Grill</h4>
<p style="padding-left: 120px;"><span style="line-height: 1.714285714; font-size: 1rem;">It will take the gentle, yet eternal, persistence that can only be provided by an electronic companion to overcome the extreme proclivity towards non-compliance that characterizes those suffering from mental illness.  QuantiModo can do this. She could always be there to inform you in a caring way when you are engaging in behaviors that exacerbate your condition (i.e. improper diet, insufficient sleep, lack of exercise, or a low degree of social interaction).</span></p>

<h1 style="padding-left: 30px;">Mental Illness is Invisible</h1>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">Those most capable of getting things done in this world are those who have won the genetic lottery and naturally possess near-optimal neurotransmitter levels.  These are the people who have the ability to get through 8 years of medical school.  It is relatively easy for healthy people to see and empathize with the pain of physical illnesses.  However, for those with mental illness, there is no language in their lungs, bridge of thought, or mental ink to convey the invisible pain they feel.</p>

<div id="magicdomid5" style="padding-left: 90px;"><b>QuantiModo Could Graphically Visualize this Pain</b></div>
<p id="magicdomid7" style="padding-left: 120px;">The Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS) developed by David Watson, Lee A. Clark, and Auke Tellegen, is a scale which uses the measure of 20 different feelings and emotions to quantify one's overall mood.</p>

<h2 style="padding-left: 30px;">Data Gathering is Currently Very Arduous</h2>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">At the present time, it requires a great deal of effort and diligence on the part of the self-tracker to gather all of the data required to identify the triggers of mental illness and quantify the effectiveness of different treatments.  Tracking ones mood, diet, sleep, activity, and medication intake can be extremely time-consuming.</p>

<h3 style="padding-left: 90px;">QuantiModo Could Make Data Acquisition Nearly Effortless</h3>
<p style="padding-left: 120px;">QuantiModo could be a friend to you, asking you questions about your day in a caring way.  Although she will be collecting data, it would just feel like a therapist letting you vent. Voice recognition may be used to quantify emotion through conscious verbal expression, spectral analysis of the magnitudes of different frequencies of speech would probably be a better means of quantifying unconscious human affect and thus providing more accurate data for the machine learning process. The user can place the burden of self-tracking on QuantiModo rather than carrying the burden themselves.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 120px;">Furthermore, <span style="font-size: 1rem;">QuantiModo could automatically retrieve information coming from a variety of sources. The data sources would include:</span></p>

<ol>
	<li><span style="line-height: 1.714285714; font-size: 1rem;">Bio-metric</span><span style="line-height: 1.714285714; font-size: 1rem;"> devices: that could measure vital signs and biomarkers</span></li>
	<li>Purchase Records: Data regarding consumption of foods and supplements could be automatically collected by and inferred from receipts or other financial aggregation services like <a href="https://www.mint.com/">mint.com</a> or <a href="https://www.slice.com">Slice</a>.</li>
	<li>Auditory Records: Voice recognition may be used to quantify emotion through conscious verbal expression, spectral analysis of the magnitudes of different frequencies of speech would probably be a better means of quantifying unconscious human affect and thus providing more accurate data for the machine learning process. <a href="http://www.sense-os.nl/commonsense">CommonSense</a> is a cloud-based platform for sensor data.</li>
	<li>Visual Affect Data via Web-Cameras: <span style="line-height: 1.714285714; font-size: 1rem;"> By tracking hundreds of points on the subjects’ face, <a href="http://sightcorp.com/">InSight</a> can accurately capture emotional states.</span></li>
	<li>Prescription Records:  Microsoft <a href="https://www.healthvault.com">Healthvault</a> can automatically collect lab results, prescription history, and visit records from a growing list of labs, pharmacies, hospitals, and clinics.</li>
</ol>
<h1 style="padding-left: 30px;">Human Bias</h1>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">To err is human.  Many different biases may influence decision-making and diagnosis in medical practice. The two primary types are:</p>

<ol>
	<li><span style="line-height: 1.714285714; font-size: 1rem;">Affective biases (intrusion of the physician's feelings and emotions)</span></li>
	<li><span style="line-height: 1.714285714; font-size: 1rem;">Cognitive biases (distortions of thinking)</span></li>
</ol>
Almost always, physician biases are unconscious. Recent research in medicine has indicated a profound impact of cognitive biases on reasoning, decision-making, and diagnosis. Common cognitive biases include, but are not limited to:
<ol>
	<li>anchoring - focusing on 1 symptom or diagnosis and failing to consider other possibilities</li>
	<li>premature closure - uncritical acceptance of an initial diagnosis</li>
	<li>search satisfaction - calling off the search when just 1 abnormality has been found</li>
	<li>availability - recent or vivid patient diagnoses are more easily brought to mind (i.e. are more available) and overemphasized in assessing the probability of a current diagnosis.</li>
</ol>
<span style="line-height: 1.714285714; font-size: 1rem;">All of these biases can interfere with reaching a correct diagnosis or recommending appropriate treatment for patients. </span>
<h2>Algorithms Do Not Lie</h2>
Patients deserve real quantitative data regarding the effectiveness rates and adverse effects of all potential treatments for individuals who share their extremely specific symptomatological profile. Their diagnosis should be algorithmic and data driven.  The Research Domain Criteria Project (RDoC) <span style="font-size: 1rem;">provides using </span><span style="font-size: 1rem;">new ways of classifying mental disorders based on dimensions of observable behavior and neurobiological measures which could be used to detect individual predictors of response.  This is the only way to ensure that each patient receives the most appropriate treatment available.</span>

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[band variation="default" inset="yes"]
[row verticallyalign="yes"]
[column width="four-tenth"]
<h1><span style="color: #000000;">Import Your Data</span></h1>
<span style="color: #000000;">QuantiModo for Android is where your tracking apps can show their true potential. Seamlessly sync a wide array of tracking apps with QuantiModo to put your data at work and find the correlations you're looking for.</span>
<h2><span style="color: #000000;">Sign In Once</span></h2>
<span style="color: #000000;">A simple sign in can mean everything. QuantiModo manages your tracking needs on Android by enabling apps to seamlessly integrate with QuantiModo. The QuantiModo SDK will soon be available for developers to help you perfect your life.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">An early version of QuantiModo for Android is currently available on Google Play. Join our <a href="https://plus.google.com/communities/100581500031158281444"><span style="color: #000000;">community</span></a> to become a tester.</span>
[/column]
[column width="six-tenth"]<img style="display: block; max-height: 250px; margin: 0 auto;" alt="marketing_responsive" src="http://images.intomobile.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/LG-and-Sony-Joining-Google-for-Next-Nexus-Devices.jpg" />

<a href="https://play.google.com/apps/testing/com.quantimodo.app">
<img style="display: block; max-height: 500px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;" alt="QuantiModo Play Store link" src="http://developer.android.com/images/brand/en_generic_rgb_wo_60.png" />
</a>
[/column]
[/row]

		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_breadcrumbs_position</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[above]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>page_options_slider_shortcode</wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>The Empirical Deficit that Plagues Modern Psychiatry</title>
		<link>http://utopia.quantimodo.com/empirical-deficit-plagues-modern-psychiatry/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 30 Sep 2013 04:20:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[quantimodo]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://quantimodo.com/?p=2177</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p dir="ltr">There is a severe quantitative deficiency in the field of clinical psychiatry. To illustrate, consider the rigorous approach that my industrial testing&nbsp;<a href="http://labinc.com/">laboratory</a> uses to identify, diagnose, and treat a relatively simple problem, such as a corroding pipe. The very subjective and qualitative approach that modern psychiatry uses to treat incomprehensibly complex problems, such as neurological disorders, looks questionable in comparison.</p>
When a power plant has a section of pipe that is rusting and failing prematurely, the following steps are taken to diagnose and treat this issue:
<ul>
	<li>
<h2>Qualitative Data Gathering</h2>
</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<ul>
	<li>We initially thoroughly interview an engineer at the plant about the plant’s processes, environment, and numerous other issues that could be related to the failure.</li>
	<li>Macroscopic and microscopic photo-documentation of the problem will also be performed.</li>
</ul>
</ol>
<ul>
	<li>
<h2>Quantitative Testing</h2>
<ul>
	<li>We analyze the corrosion products using energy or wavelength dispersive spectrometry. This determines the elemental composition of the corrosion products and quantifies any corrosive species that may be present.</li>
	<li>We use spectrometric analytical techniques to determine the chemical composition of the pipe. &nbsp;This will allow us to ascertain the degree of corrosion resistance that can be expected from this material based on published materials science research data.</li>
	<li>We cross-section the failed area of the pipe to analyze its microstructure. This allows us to gain insight into whether or not physical stress or thermal factors were involved in the failure.</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>
<h2>Research Into Causes and Potential Remedies</h2>
<ul>
	<li>Guided by the issue-specific data obtained from the testing, various databases and sources of materials research will be scoured to determine the most likely cause of and solution to the problem.</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
Contrast this with a modern clinical psychiatrist’s treatment for an individual suffering from a problem as unfathomably complex as neurological dysfunction.

I was suicidal. &nbsp;I saw psychiatrist after psychiatrist. They would talk to me about my problems and feelings for about a half an hour and prescribe me some drug based on their intuition and experience. There's no quantitative testing to try to determine a root cause. There's no research to see if they can figure out what is currently the most effective treatment for my specific subtype of mental illness. There is no quantitative tracking of the efficacy of the prescribed treatment. &nbsp;There's no tracking of adverse effects of said treatment.

After over a decade of failure by the medical community, I decided to bring the same techniques I use to solve problems in my laboratory to solve my psychological problem. &nbsp;I started doing my own research, self-quantification, and analysis.

I read a lot of books on neuroscience, including the following:
<ul>
	<li><a href="http://stahlonline.cambridge.org/">Stahl’s Essential Psychopharmacology</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.biopsychiatry.com/">The Good Drug Guide</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.dummies.com/store/product/Cognitive-Behavioural-Therapy-For-Dummies-2nd-Edition.productCd-0470665416.html">Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Dummies</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.thegreatcourses.com/tgc/courses/course_detail.aspx?cid=1540">Neuroscience of Everyday Life</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.thegreatcourses.com/tgc/courses/course_detail.aspx?cid=1540http://www.amazon.com/Buddhas-Brain-Practical-Neuroscience-Happiness/dp/1572246952">Buddha’s Brain: The Practical Science of Happiness, Love, and Wisdom</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.rainybrainsunnybrain.com/">Rainy Brain, Sunny Brain: The New Science of Optimism and Pessimism</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.randomhouse.com/kvpa/gilbert/">Stumbling on Happiness</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://thehowofhappiness.com/">The How of Happiness</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://cordeliafine.com/a_mind_of_its_own.html">A Mind of Its Own</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.ted.com/talks/mihaly_csikszentmihalyi_on_flow.html">Flow: The Secret to Happiness</a></li>
	<li><a  href='http://paltip.com/https:..quantimodo.com/!1be4g' target="_blank">Meet Your Happy Chemicals</a></li>
</ul>
I started experimenting with many different medications and supplements. I tried cognitive behavioral therapy and transcendental meditation. I even built my own cranial&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cranial_electrotherapy_stimulation">electrostimulation device</a> that I used to pass 2 milliamperes of current through my brain. I tracked the effectiveness of my attempts.
<p dir="ltr">Eventually, I found an NMDA-antagonist that has been shown to be effective for many individuals with a myriad of symptoms similar to my own. I presented this research to my psychiatrist. He refused to prescribe the drug because it's not approved by the FDA for use with depression.</p>
<p dir="ltr">The drug was invented in 1969 and originally was approved to treat Alzheimer's disease. &nbsp;By the time anyone realized it was effective at treating depression, it was out of patent. &nbsp;At this point, the potential profits to be made by any given manufacturer would be exceeded by the billion-dollar price tag that goes along with 10 years of FDA-required clinical trials.</p>
<p dir="ltr">My psychiatrist legally could have prescribed it to me for an off-label usage. He didn’t. I presume this refusal was out of concern over potential liability issues. Regardless, there’s no reason why I shouldn’t be able to just buy this drug over the counter. Its risk profile is lower than that of alcohol.</p>
<p dir="ltr">Anyway, due to the FDA’s backwards and restrictive policies, I was forced to hire a pharmaceutical company in a less medically oppressive country (China, ironically) to make it for me. I tested it at my lab to verify the purity. Then I began administration. The results were nothing short of miraculous.</p>
<p dir="ltr">Starting the medication felt like the first time I put on glasses. I was shocked and amazed to discover how beautiful the world was to normal people. Life was suddenly so much easier. I had tons of spare brain capacity now that I previously devoted to constantly hypothesizing about the infinite reasons that everyone hated me.</p>
<p dir="ltr">If the FDA had their way, my medication would have been intercepted by customs. I saw a story on 60 Minutes where customs agents gloated over a massive pile of overseas drugs they had confiscated. I'm quite certain that there are suicide victims rotting in the ground right now because the United States government prevents people from getting the medications they need.</p>
<p dir="ltr">We need to remove the barriers to self-experimentation. We must bring psychiatry into the 21st century. We must turn the treatment of mental illness into a science rather than an art that only slightly exceeds humoral psychology. We need to restore our right to the pursuit of happiness.</p>
&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[There is a severe quantitative deficiency in the field of clinical psychiatry. To illustrate, consider the rigorous approach that my industrial testing laboratory uses to identify, diagnose, and treat a relatively simple problem, such as a corroding pipe. The very subjective and qualitative approach that modern psychiatry uses to treat incomprehensibly complex problems, such as neurological disorders, looks questionable in comparison.]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>

	<item>
				<title>RescueTime</title>
		<link>http://utopia.quantimodo.com/portfolio/rescuetime/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 11 Oct 2013 00:48:49 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[quantimodo]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://quantimo.do/?post_type=portfolio&#038;p=2340</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="https://www.rescuetime.com/rp/quantimodo" target="_blank"><img class="aligncenter size-medium wp-image-2438" alt="rescuetimelogo" src="https://quantimo.do/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/rescuetimelogo-300x300.png" width="300" height="300" /></a></p>

<h2><a href="https://www.rescuetime.com/rp/quantimodo" target="_blank">RescueTime</a></h2>
<a href="https://www.rescuetime.com/rp/quantimodo" target="_blank">RescueTime</a> is an automatic time and attention tracker that helps individuals and teams propagate good processes and eliminate bad habits.   Users install it on their computer and mobile device to analyze time usage.

<a href="https://www.rescuetime.com/rp/quantimodo">RescueTime</a> for Android tracks how users spend time on their mobile device.  It notes how much time is spent on apps and phone calls.  The app then reports an efficiency score, top distractions, and categories of activity on the user's mobile device.    The stopwatch tool allows users to manually track events such as meetings and exercise.  Users can then set the productivity as they finish, without visiting the website.  The mobile app works great on its own but even better when combined with the desktop application.

All new users receive 14 days of Pro Web Reporting mode.  After the trial period it reverts to free mode until upgraded from the <a href="https://www.rescuetime.com/rp/quantimodo">RescueTime</a> site.  Pro Solo RescueTime costs US $9.00 a month, full year at a discounted $72.00, if you want to keep premium services.

Free version is free!  One account is all users need to track all of their devices.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Fluxtream</title>
		<link>http://utopia.quantimodo.com/portfolio/fluxtream/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 19 Oct 2013 19:50:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[quipeace@gmail.com]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://quantimo.do/?post_type=portfolio&#038;p=2549</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="https://quantimo.do/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/connector-fluxtream_capture.png"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-2550" alt="fluxtream" src="https://quantimo.do/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/connector-fluxtream_capture.png" width="158" height="89" /></a>

Fluxtream is a personal analytics tool that helps you track your daily habits, identify your strengths and weaknesses, and get a comprehensive view on your self-tracking devices and the services that you use to organize your life.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>project_details_enable</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[on]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>project_details_project_url</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>project_details_client_name</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>project_details_client_url</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>testimonial_show_testimonial</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[-1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Perfect Your Life</title>
		<link>http://utopia.quantimodo.com/perfect/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 19 Oct 2013 04:04:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[mike_sinn]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://quantimo.do/?p=2552</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[gap height="30"]

[row]

You deserve to be happy.  Some people have won the genetic lottery and are naturally happy.  However, for some of us, happiness requires a lot of work.  I am a member of the latter group.  These are the steps that I had to take to attain happiness.

&nbsp;
<h1>Step 1: Diagnosis</h1>
<a href="http://whatsmym3.com/" target="new">What's My M3?</a> provides a three minute test for depression, anxiety, bipolar disorder and PTSD to diagnose the specific <a href="http://health.usnews.com/health-news/family-health/brain-and-behavior/articles/2010/03/09/feeling-depressed-or-anxious-screen-yourself-online" target="new">subtype</a> of mental illness.
<h2 style="text-align: left;">Step 2: Treatment Determination</h2>
<p style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;"><a href="http://curetogether.com/" target="new">Cure Together</a> provides a crowdsourced list of <a href="http://curetogether.com/depression/ig/treatment-effectiveness-vs-popularity" target="new">treatments</a> in order by their rate of effectiveness at alleviating:</p>

<ul style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;">
	<li style="padding-left: 30px;">​<a href="http://curetogether.com/depression/treatments/pmi/" target="new">Depression</a></li>
	<li style="padding-left: 30px;"><a href="http://curetogether.com/anxiety/treatments/pmi/" target="new">Anxiety</a></li>
	<li style="padding-left: 30px;"><a href="http://curetogether.com/bipolar-disorder/treatments/pmi/" target="new">Bipolar Disorder</a></li>
	<li style="padding-left: 30px;"><a href="http://curetogether.com/ptsd/treatments/pmi/" target="new">PTSD</a></li>
	<li style="padding-left: 30px;"><a href="http://curetogether.com/social-anxiety-disorder/treatments/pmi/" target="new">Social Anxiety Disorder</a></li>
	<li style="padding-left: 30px;"><a href="http://curetogether.com/seasonal-affective-disorder/treatments/pmi/" target="new">Seasonal Affective Disorder</a></li>
	<li style="padding-left: 30px;"><a href="http://curetogether.com/attention-deficit-hyperactivity-disorder/treatments/pmi/" target="new">Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder</a></li>
	<li style="padding-left: 30px;"><a href="http://curetogether.com/obsessive-compulsive-disorder/treatments/pmi/" target="new">Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder </a></li>
	<li style="padding-left: 30px;"><a href="http://curetogether.com/schizophrenia/treatments/pmi/" target="new">Schizophrenia</a></li>
</ul>
<h2 style="text-align: left;">Step 3: Safety Information</h2>
<p style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;"><a href="https://www.mediguard.org/" target="new">Mediguard</a> can be used to perform safety checks to screen for potential drug-drug and drug-disease interactions.</p>

<h2 style="text-align: left;">Step 4: Treatment Tracking</h2>
<p style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;">Individuals can then use self-tracking <a href="http://quantimodo.com/blog/quantimodo-comparison-matrix-for-quanitified-self-apps-devices-that-track-specific-variables/" target="new">applications</a> and devices to track their treatments.</p>

<ul style="padding-left: 30px;">
	<li style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;"><a href="http://www.myfitnesspal.com/" target="new">My Fitness Pal</a> allows users to track their diet and exercise.</li>
	<li style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;"><a href="http://www.medisafeproject.com/" target="new">Medisafe</a> allows users to track their medication consumption.</li>
	<li style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;"><a href="http://paltip.com/quantimodo/!7nru">Zeo</a> uses electroencephalography (EEG) to track the quality of your sleep.</li>
	<li style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;"><a href="http://www.shareasale.com/r.cfm?b=286239&amp;u=816880&amp;m=31379&amp;urllink=&amp;afftrack=">Fitbit</a> tracks steps, distance, calories burned, floors climbed and sleep cycle.</li>
	<li style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;"><a href="http://paltip.com/quantimodo/!7nrt">BodyMedia</a> daily energy expenditure and energy intake using an accelerometer, heat flux sensor, galvanic skin response sensor, skin temperature sensor, and a near-body ambient temperature sensor.</li>
	<li style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;"><a href="https://www.moodscope.com">Moodscope</a> is an online mood-tracking system which enables individuals to accurately measure and record daily mood scores which are automatically tracked on a graph and, with an individual’s agreement, emailed each day to one or more trusted friends who have agreed to keep an eye on the user. It is based on a previously well-validated daily mood measure, the PANAS (Watson et al, 1988), which means that mood is measured in an accurate and scientific way.</li>
	<li style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;"><a href="http://www.shareasale.com/r.cfm?b=481603&amp;u=816880&amp;m=31379&amp;urllink=&amp;afftrack=">FLEX WIRELESS ACTIVITY &amp; SLEEP WRISTBAND</a> tracks steps, distance, and calories burned. At night, it tracks your sleep quality and wakes you silently in the morning.</li>
	<li style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;"><a href="http://paltip.com/quantimodo/!7ns4" target="_blank">Nike+ Fuel Band</a> - Track calories burned, steps taken, and intensity of physical activity. See the progress in real time on band’s LED display or on the mobile app. Data is synced to mobile app (via Bluetooth) or computer (via USB cable). Compete with friends, and receive achievement and rewards. The band is easily adjustable to fit wrist of any size. Operates on 2 standard lithium batteries.</li>
	<li style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;">Polar FT7 Heart Rate Monitor</li>
</ul>
<h2 style="text-align: left;">Step 5: ​Biometric Monitoring to Identify Adverse Events</h2>
<p style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;">Since safety is of critical importance in any self-experimentation, individuals should engage in rigorous tracking of their vital signs to identify if they drift outside acceptable ranges. Any treatments that produce unacceptable side effects should be immediately terminated. This will allow for safe self-experimentation.</p>

<ul style="padding-left: 30px;">
	<li style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;">The <a href="http://paltip.com/quantimodo/!7nr2">Withings Smart Blood Pressure Monitor</a> provides easy and precise self-measurement of your blood pressure and heart rate.</li>
	<li style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;">The <a href="http://paltip.com/quantimodo/!7nrx" target="_blank">Zephyr HxM Bluetooth Wireless Heart Rate Sensor for Android and Windows Phone 8</a> or the <a href="http://paltip.com/quantimodo/!7ns2">Zephyr HxM Smart Heart Rate Monitor for iPhone 4S, iPad (3rd Gen) &amp; iPhone 5 with Bluetooth Smart (4.0)</a> in conjunction with the app <a href="http://www.myfitnesscompanion.com/" target="new">My Fitness Companion</a> can track your pulse to identify if it drifts outside acceptable ranges.</li>
	<li style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;"><a href="http://www.shareasale.com/r.cfm?b=465966&amp;u=816880&amp;m=46402&amp;urllink=&amp;afftrack=">Tinké</a> can measure heart rate, respiratory rate and blood oxygen saturation to quantify cardiorespiratory wellness.</li>
	<li style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;">The <a href="http://paltip.com/quantimodo/!7nqo" target="_blank">Zephry BioHarness</a> is pretty damn expensive, but it can provide an electrocardiogram (ECG), determine one's R-R interval, breathing rate, monitor posture, activity level, and measure peak acceleration.</li>
	<li style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;"><a href="http://paltip.com/quantimodo/!7nqp" target="_blank">Heartmath 6400 Inner Balance Sensor</a> for iOS is an innovative approach to improving wellness through training, education and self-monitoring. InnerBalance shows you your heart rhythm pattern (HRV), a breathing pacer to go along with your heart rhythms, and on-screen coaching - training you how to change your physiology to a healthier, coherent state.</li>
</ul>
<h2 style="text-align: left;">Step 6: ​Tracking the Effectiveness of Treatments</h2>
<ul>
	<li style="text-align: left;"><a href="https://www.moodscope.com/">Moodscope</a> - Moodscope is an entirely service-user-developed online mood-tracking and feedback tool with built-in social support, designed to stabilize and improve mood.</li>
	<li style="text-align: left;"><a href="https://quantimodo.com/apps/android/">MoodiModo</a> - MoodiModo is currently available as a beta on Google Play. Join our <a href="https://plus.google.com/communities/100581500031158281444">community</a> to become a tester.</li>
</ul>
<h2 style="text-align: left;">Step 7: ​Integrate and Analyze Your Data to Find Out What Works</h2>
<p style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;"><a href="https://quantimodo.com//" target="new">Quantimodo</a> can help by synergizing, visualizing, and analyzing the cacophony data to identify correlations between specific input factors and treatments (independent variables) and mood outcomes (dependent variables). The <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pearson_product-moment_correlation_coefficient" target="new">Pearson product-moment correlation coefficient</a> derived from an XY scatterplot of input behaviours and output states can quantify the effectiveness of various treatments.</p>
<p style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;">The human mind is not powerful enough to keep track of the countless factors that go into producing an emotional state. Timeline graphical analysis can help to identify potential confounding uncontrolled variables that may be contaminating the results of an experiment.</p>
<p style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;">Fine-grained, personalized minimum effective dosages can be established.  Degrees of drug tolerance and withdrawal symptoms can be quantified.  By integrating the area under the mood curves, true cost-benefit analyses weighing therapeutic benefits against adverse effects can be performed.</p>

<h2>Crowdsourcing Positive Psychology Research</h2>
<p style="text-align: left;">Data can be anonymized and aggregated with the data from other users suffering from the same subtype of mental illness. Effectiveness rates can then be extrapolated from user data.  The best available defense against the possibility of spurious results due to confounding is often to dispense with efforts at stratification and instead conduct a <a title="Randomization" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Randomization">randomized study</a> of a <a title="Law of large numbers" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_of_large_numbers">sufficiently large</a> sample taken as a whole, such that all potential confounding variables (known and unknown) will be distributed by chance across all study groups and hence will be uncorrelated with the binary variable for inclusion/exclusion in any group. Over time, this data collection can recursively improve the accuracy of the presented effectiveness rates for the various treatments.</p>

<center><iframe src="http://www.youtube.com/embed/vDlgfLTE4g0" height="315" width="420" allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0"></iframe></center>
<h2>Genetics</h2>
<p style="text-align: left;">Eventually, genetic information provided by services such as <a href="https://www.23andme.com/">23andMe</a> will help predict not only an individual patient's response to some medications, but also the likelihood of <a href="http://blog.lexi.com/blog/drug-interaction-data" target="_blank">drug interactions</a> and adverse effects.</p>

<h2>The End of Mental Illness</h2>
<p style="text-align: left;">Adequate exercise, diet, and sleep in conjunction with appropriate pharmacological measures and other treatments can and will eradicate mental illness from the face of the earth.  All we need is our will and the scientific method.</p>
<p style="text-align: left;"><a href="https://quantimodo.com/help/"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2172" alt="help us eradicate mental illness button" src="https://quantimodo.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/help-us-eradicate-mental-illness-button.png" width="455" height="58" /></a></p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>

	<item>
				<title>MoodiModo for Android</title>
		<link>http://utopia.quantimodo.com/?p=2597</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[quantimodo]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://quantimo.do/?p=2597</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[band variation="default" inset="yes"] [row verticallyalign="yes"] [/row] [band variation="default" backgroundimage="http://www.euged.com/demo/metrolium/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/band_1.jpg" inset="yes"] [row verticallyalign="yes"] [column width="four-tenth"] <img style="display: block; max-height: 500px; margin: 0 auto;" alt="MoodiModo on device" src="http://i.imgur.com/fjtvuFU.png" /> <a href="https://play.google.com/apps/testing/com.quantimodo.mood"> <img style="display: block; max-height: 500px; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;" alt="MoodiModo Play Store link" src="http://developer.android.com/images/brand/en_generic_rgb_wo_60.png" /> </a> [/column] [column width="five-tenth"]
<p dir="ltr">Mental health is THE greatest unmet need of our time. About half of the people you know will develop a mental illness at some point during their lifetime. Over 50 million Americans currently suffer from some form of mental illness. MoodiModo is intended to help those who suffer from mood disorders such as <a href="http://www.nimh.nih.gov/health/topics/depression/index.shtml">major depressive disorder</a>, <a href="http://www.nimh.nih.gov/health/topics/depression/index.shtml">dysthymic disorder</a>, and <a href="http://www.nimh.nih.gov/health/topics/bipolar-disorder/index.shtml">bipolar disorder</a>.</p>
<p dir="ltr">You can’t manage what you don’t measure. Hence, it is crucial that mood be continually tracked and quantified in order to assess the effectiveness of various treatments. Those suffering from depression are characteristically non-compliant towards most avenues of treatment, including mood tracking.</p>
<p dir="ltr">MoodiModo makes tracking of one’s mood effortless by using a unique pop-up reminder interface that forces the user to rate their mood at regular intervals. When the user first installs the app, they get to set this reminder frequency and indicate their preferred means of notification, as well as reporting their first mood, engaging the user from the moment they start using MoodiModo.</p>
<p dir="ltr">In addition to the ability to track basic overall mood, MoodiModo also allows the user to submit a more detailed and precise measurement of their mood when time allows. This is done by answering questions related to the 20 different feelings and emotions defined by the Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS). The PANAS is a scale which was developed by Auke Tellegen in the Department of Psychology at the University of Minnesota and David Watson and Lee Anna Clark in the Department of Psychology at the University of Iowa to provide brief measures of positive and negative affect. The PANAS scales were originally published in the Journal of Personality and Social Psychology in 1988.</p>
<p dir="ltr">Users will have the ability to review their mood trends retrospectively, allowing them to identify triggers for symptoms and quantify the effectiveness of treatments. The social sharing features of MoodiModo would facilitate social support that is a critical element to recovery from these disorders. MoodiModo allows the user to easily share graphs of their mood on various social media websites such as Facebook, Google+, Twitter, Tumblr, and Pinterest. This will inform friends and family when someone is suffering.  Since emotional states are often invisible, visual depiction of emotion can ensure that no one ever needs to suffer alone in silence.</p>
<p dir="ltr">Physical and environmental factors influence how you feel, just as emotions often cause changes in your physical system. There are 100 billion neurons in the human brain, and each of them is busy most of the time constantly sending tiny electrical impulses from one brain cell to another.  This signaling is modulated by chemicals called neurotransmitters. This activity is the biochemical basis of feelings.</p>
<p dir="ltr">In turn, brain chemistry is influenced by a number of factors including degree of social interaction, sleep, diet, medication, and physical activity. Mood data from MoodiModo can also be automatically uploaded to the QuantiModo website.  At QuantiModo, this data can be combined with data from other applications, devices and electronic health records.  Since the human mind is not powerful enough to retain all of the necessary information, this data integration feature is essential to identifying correlations and causal relationships.</p>
<p dir="ltr">Users will also have the option to anonymously donate their data to the Mind First Foundation, the Personal Genome Project, and other researchers in order to help facilitate the crowdsourced observational research which will eventually lead to the eradication of mental illness.</p>
MoodiModo is currently available as a beta on Google Play. Join our <a href="https://plus.google.com/communities/100581500031158281444">community</a> to become a tester. [/column] [/row] [gap height="30"] [band variation="default" paddingtop="75px" paddingbottom="75px" inset="yes"] [row verticallyalign="yes"] [column width="three-fifth" offset="one-fifth"]
<h1 style="text-align: center;">Voice Your Mind</h1>
<p style="text-align: center;">We've built these apps specifically for you, and we'd love to hear back! Voice your mind on UserVoice and help us make Quantimodo an even happier place.</p>
[gap height="20"]
<p style="text-align: center;">[button link="http://quantimodo.uservoice.com/" target="_blank"]To our UserVoice![/button]</p>
[/column] [/row]]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[MoodiModo makes tracking of one’s mood effortless by using a unique pop-up reminder interface that forces the user to rate their mood at regular intervals.]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2597</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-10-21 22:22:26</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>0000-00-00 00:00:00</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>draft</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="apps"><![CDATA[Apps]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_thumbnail_id</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2429]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Moodscope</title>
		<link>http://utopia.quantimodo.com/portfolio/moodscope/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 28 Oct 2013 02:45:32 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[mike_sinn]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://quantimo.do/?post_type=portfolio&#038;p=2638</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="https://www.moodscope.com/">MoodScope</a> is a web based application for measuring, tracking and sharing your mood. Moods are measured using an online card game, and can be shared automatically by email with friends, with the idea that these activities can raise mood in and of themselves. The mood log can be charted to see progressions and as a way to identify events that may have influenced your mood.

<a href="https://quantimo.do/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/moodscope-logo.png"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-2639 aligncenter" alt="moodscope logo" src="https://quantimo.do/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/moodscope-logo.png" width="336" height="56" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Genomera</title>
		<link>http://utopia.quantimodo.com/portfolio/genomera/</link>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://genomera.com/">Genomera </a>seeks to heal the world through personal health collaboration.

They currently provide a platform for group health science, enabling participants to design and operate scientific health studies. A form of crowd-sourced clinical trials.

<a href="http://genomera.com/"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-2642" alt="genomera logo" src="https://quantimo.do/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/genomera-logo.jpg" width="160" height="41" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Personal Experiments</title>
		<link>http://utopia.quantimodo.com/?p=2657</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[quantimodo]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://quantimo.do/?p=2657</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Ideas for Personal Experiments
<ol>
	<li>Vary how dark your room is when you sleep. Measure 1. how long you sleep. 2. how rested you feel when you wake up.</li>
	<li></li>
</ol>
&nbsp;

<a href="https://www.personalexperiments.org/">https://www.personalexperiments.org/</a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>dosIQ</title>
		<link>http://utopia.quantimodo.com/?p=2662</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[mike_sinn]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://quantimo.do/?p=2662</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>Take a look at
what you're eating.</h1>
Follow users on your diet(s), vote, encourage, and find new meals.

&nbsp;

<a href="https://www.dosiq.com/">https://www.dosiq.com/</a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2662</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-10-31 03:35:42</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>0000-00-00 00:00:00</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>draft</wp:status>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[3]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Happiness in an Endogenous Phenomenon</title>
		<link>http://utopia.quantimodo.com/happiness-in-an-endogenous-phenomenon/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 12 Nov 2013 17:57:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[mike_sinn]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://quantimo.do/?p=2791</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The name QuantiModo is derived from Quasimodo<b>, </b><i><a title="The Hunchback of Notre-Dame" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Hunchback_of_Notre-Dame">The Hunchback of Notre-Dame</a></i>. Since Quasimodo was born with a hunchback, the townspeople just saw him as a hideously misshapen monster. However, those townspeople were idiots (as most townspeople are).  For within that deformed figure resided a beautiful human spirit.  The Latin words "quasi" and "modo" mean "almost" and "the standard measure" respectively. As such, Quasimodo is "almost the standard measure" of a human being. QuantiModo intends to be the full measure of a human being.

Like Quasimodo, life-tracking data in it's natural form  appears to be a hideous mess of numbers in spreadsheets. However, within this cacophony of data lies something very beautiful, the secrets to maximizing your happiness.

Like true beauty, true happiness is an endogenous phenomenon, meaning that it comes from within.  Happiness can be <em>influenced</em> by environmental stimuli. However, contrary to popular belief, happiness is <strong>not solely determined</strong> by environmental stimuli.

This has been proven in many scientific studies. For example, lottery winners experience extreme elation in the weeks following their win. However, after a matter of months, they generally drift back down to their genetically predetermined hedonic set point. Conversely, after an initial severe depression, new paraplegics generally return to the same level of happiness they had prior to their accidents.

Happiness does not correlate with health, wealth, education or status. But it does correlate with many small things we can now do in our everyday lives. You <strong>can</strong> raise your emotional set-point.

I would like to give you an example of a person who had every reason in the world to be miserable, yet eternally remained in a maniacally happy state.  This woman was an employee at my laboratory. She and her little brother were abandoned by their parents at a very young age.  Her brother was her sole companion at the time. Around the age of 6, she and her brother went to stay with their father.  Their father happened to be an alcoholic and managed to set their trailer on fire.  Her brother burned to death in this accident.  Later in life, she had two children.  Both of these children possessed behavioral and learning disabilities.  The fathers of these children provided very little support.  A short time before I had met her, she was in an automobile accident which shattered her leg, resulting in chronic pain and a severe limp.  Despite all of these challenges, she was literally the happiest person I had ever met before.  It was almost obnoxious how happy she was all the time.

Conversely, there are people like Kurt Cobain, who have attained success beyond their wildest dreams and have every reason in the world to be ecstatic, but kill themselves to end the pain caused by neurotransmitter imbalance.  This is all evidence that our emotions are merely a product of biochemical reactions.

I am living proof that it is possible to manipulate these biochemical reactions and attain sustained happiness. Since childhood, I had always dreamed of blowing my brains out. My depressed brain was as resistant to treatment as anyone's. I attempted to find relief from my own psychological problem within the medical community for over a decade.  Finally, I decided to employ the same techniques I had used in my industrial testing laboratory to find a solution.

The first step is research.  I found the following books extremely helpful in gaining a full understanding of how our biochemistry produces our emotional states.
<div dir="ltr">
<table><colgroup> <col width="156" /> <col width="468" /></colgroup>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><img alt="" src="https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/tDOAVCKwvnqY7s-ktiQs2FtvokD5CZpoOx-HqW_-NNfujer5VZgx0NLkSS0uuI-smYQBBbS2fzGIwTdFujS3JRA3tSh_oXY-KrMjQgma3zeEQPt57JtlSnHf4g" width="106px;" height="139px;" /></td>
<td>
<h2 dir="ltr"><a href="http://books.google.com/books?id=BBtMzTV8OMgC&amp;printsec=frontcover&amp;source=gbs_ge_summary_r&amp;cad=0#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false">Stahl’s Essential Psychopharmacology</a></h2>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><img alt="" src="https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/Jk4H3dR5s10mG10ITC80fvgEqehF6CJZhkkTemjJDO7hsWVptXCPZa2AQTRXZoImTDK9s7aY-hdxezMN7tWmzcZ70KwZiOG9GTWEQz_u46dlwrj9fiL0wzh-hw" width="121px;" height="100px;" /></td>
<td>
<h2 dir="ltr"><a href="http://www.biopsychiatry.com/">The Good Drug Guide</a></h2>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><img alt="" src="https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/txXDJZc_y81AXqUd-fbecUJmOJYdMSq5QqCEeeidpz8heWKm6duCNs-hdcMqQ2nVhT6a9XS-neefOlvWd-n9sV6ZDbPFnO80aSgT63Cn44M1oEWzkKcpu2lGYQ" width="100px;" height="125px;" /></td>
<td>
<h2 dir="ltr"><a href="http://www.dummies.com/store/product/Cognitive-Behavioural-Therapy-For-Dummies-2nd-Edition.productCd-0470665416.html">Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Dummies</a></h2>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><img alt="" src="https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/iK1qnR1Qdg6HR9x0YR6HmuSPN5Eb5iHc9JbXAEijHQnqJ7zuBDRjd25bTVLeWTKm7IpopuQ_oLUZ7sUh-o5a9jAE1B4h_Tfd2NGltN2hkHg9IB7KgfpgSj_Hkw" width="114px;" height="126px;" /></td>
<td>
<h2 dir="ltr"><a href="http://www.thegreatcourses.com/tgc/courses/course_detail.aspx?cid=1540">Neuroscience of Everyday Life</a></h2>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><img alt="" src="https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/LrfmFeQkr8BUEX3TOVUP6_Vaeuf7Yqhoyn1vkhqtwoaIXIKZ4WvhmcrJ7z73lxThHtliyewmztLO6irKgEJ1xqkq10UsCko5DC03B0zcnpIFpYaq2illmPxXPA" width="112px;" height="166px;" /></td>
<td>
<h2 dir="ltr"><a href="http://www.rickhanson.net/writings/buddhas-brain">Buddha’s Brain: The Practical Neuroscience of Happiness, Love, and Wisdom</a></h2>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><img alt="" src="https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/TPzy5VICcdQ4gu9ZNhZDkExEqFEawJquOPm9KWZfRV1HW-8fFQAlM9jEz1ECsD7IcU3KW2rg65ptrRjrEYFTVJf3zf9lhkWVAwUJe_dEfO53nVQ27LV4mRE90w" width="105px;" height="153px;" /></td>
<td>
<h2 dir="ltr"><a href="http://www.rainybrainsunnybrain.com/">Rainy Brain, Sunny Brain: The New Science of Optimism and Pessimism</a></h2>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><img alt="" src="https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/gKe3wdhSc6Bjy6I0_2_KC3RHGTgfa_b5TUzL3w0aysxOxLdNU4P5p1wwv1-hSm9-_JI4eCHWNKqrgLk9fZdKb5tWRmYK7gkWCesgMp-xvyglyWKvZVpUXGccpg" width="105px;" height="162px;" /></td>
<td>
<h2 dir="ltr"><a href="http://thehowofhappiness.com/">The How of Happiness</a></h2>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><img alt="" src="https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/iTQMQ_PNMUXaYRo1QOcNM9FmZFiLhW6bblZc548nyOfC_naxX1Uzi3vq8yotwpQNpzp9hfs_PleB7vfehYnHM7TTQZbKhQx-sy0grbJBXXJhUGeUGtGqT7AyWQ" width="105px;" height="148px;" /></td>
<td>
<h2 dir="ltr"><a href="http://cordeliafine.com/a_mind_of_its_own.html">A Mind of Its Own</a></h2>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><img alt="" src="https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/3SmVuakDcaGcJ4qrYFUJjgeSQ0PA4B4g-tZ8Bt359-GoGVjvvDgMmY3fsIFKYFhxLqhbqN_dN7tm-Xw3RLcZgmwHeOT6R4kCxz0Gh1cgo9LBehRLaxBRGHSyMA" width="105px;" height="158px;" /></td>
<td>
<h2 dir="ltr"><a href="http://www.ted.com/talks/mihaly_csikszentmihalyi_on_flow.html">Flow: The Secret to Happiness</a></h2>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><img alt="" src="https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/Ieyi0DtKZ4b8N_3s7EBh5BE-2VK-uXKGCTsUIZ7EA_-1CiquHeCSY77Q9aPv6mC6vEF3IBu_S_DhLMUpHs-caI6lHJkksWYTBht1LqJovy3aXSD_AoC73jnyRg" width="106px;" height="162px;" /></td>
<td>
<h2 dir="ltr"><a href="http://www.psychologytoday.com/files/attachments/59029/happy-chemicals.pdf">Meet Your Happy Chemicals</a></h2>
</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
<h1>From my experimentation, I've found the necessary (but not necessarily sufficient) conditions for happiness are:</h1>
<h2><strong>Exercise</strong></h2>
I hate exercise.  It feels like such a waste of time. You have to go to the gym and people look at you. It just sucks.  Unfortunately, I've found that I have to elevate my heart rate above 150 beats per minute several times a week to avoid being miserable.  There are several reasons that exercise increases happiness.
<ul>
	<li><strong>Lower Epinephrine Levels</strong> - Variation in the degree of cardiovascular activity can lower circulating epinephrine levels. Epinephrine is the chemical messenger responsible for the body's "fight or flight" response to danger or stress. Lower levels mean less stress.</li>
	<li><strong>Higher BDNF Levels</strong> - Physical activity also increases the expression of the brain derived neurothophic factor (BDNF).   BDNF promotes the survival of serotonin receptors, the activation of which is is associated with a sense of well-being and pleasure.</li>
	<li><strong>Endorphin Release</strong> - Another factor is endorphins, the chemicals released in response to stress or pain. When endorphins lock into opioid receptors, they block the transmission of pain signals and also produce a euphoric feeling like opiates do.</li>
</ul>
<h2><strong>Adequate Sleep</strong></h2>
This also feels like a huge waste of 219,000 hours of your life.  However, it seems also to be a necessary evil.  Sleep deprivation can increase levels of corticosterone (a stress hormone), resulting in fewer new brain cells being created in your hippocampus.  The inhibition of this <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neurogenesis" target="_blank">neurogenesis</a> is linked to the development of depression.

Blue light can reduce quality of sleep even when your <a title="'Preliminary evidence that light through the eyelids can suppress melatonin and phase shift dim light melatonin onset', Figueiro &amp; Rei 2012" href="http://www.biomedcentral.com/content/pdf/1756-0500-5-221.pdf">eyes are shut</a>. Blue light activates retinal ganglion cells containing melanopsin and reduces the production of melatonin, decreasing sleep efficiency.  Computer programs like <a href="http://justgetflux.com/">f.lux</a> and wearing Blu-Blockers for a few hours before bed are helpful in preventing this. However, I personally prefer to put Blu-Blockers on as a shocker several hours before bedtime (primarily for the sake of vanity).

http://youtu.be/_Png-PC0ews
<strong></strong>
<h2>Proper Diet</h2>
For me, this means complete avoidance of gluten.  For those with this sensitivity, gluten causes the body's immune system to produce an excess of a protein called zonulin in the small intestine.  The wall of your gut has a bunch of, what you might call, "bouncer" cells that decide what enters your bloodstream and what remains waste.  An excess of zonulin can force these cells open too wide and let things through that really shouldn’t be going through. (i.e. poop, but don't tell anybody, because that's just gross.)

Another unfortunate side effect of my immune system's over-reaction to gluten is the destruction of the hair-like villi protruding from the wall of my intestine. The job of the villi is to increase the surface area and help you snag more of the nutrients from your food.  When my immune system responds to gluten it makes the mistake of attacking the villi too.  This shortens them, reducing the surface area of my gut and reducing my ability to extract nutrients.  One of these nutrients is the amino acid tryptophan, the precursor to serotonin. Thus, gluten could cause a serotonin deficiency in this manner,

Overall, I found the result of gluten consumption is lethargy, low self-esteem, a negative outlook, difficulty getting out of bed, autistic-like symptoms, obsessive-compulsive disorder (It's weird. Whenever I eat it, I find myself wasting a shameful amount of time doing stupid stuff like finding  a new background image for my phone.), and what the French call "ennui".
<h2>When all else fails...</h2>
Even after these basic preconditions for happiness were met, I was still miserable. So I started researching, self-quantification, and analysis.  I went on to experiment with many different medications and supplements. I tried cognitive behavioral therapy and transcendental meditation. I even built my own cranial <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cranial_electrotherapy_stimulation">electrostimulation device</a> that I used to pass 2 milliamperes of current through my brain. I tracked the effectiveness of my attempts. Through my research, I found a wide array of treatments were required to keep me from reverting to my extremely low natural hedonic set point.
<h2 dir="ltr">Good Bacteria</h2>
One discovery that I never would have made without self-tracking is the importance of probiotics. There is a Filipino gentleman that works at my lab.  His wife works for an over-the-counter pharmaceutical company.  As a result, they receive boxes of free random OTC products. Since he is an extremely generous fellow, he would give these to the employees at my lab.  One item that I saw when perusing this box was called ProBiotics Plus.  The claim on the packaging was that it "supported immune system and digestive health".  When originally looking at it, I thought to myself, "that's some worthless new-age, hippie crap."  However, I do happen to kind of like immune system and digestive health, so I decided to take some, thinking that it at least wouldn't hurt anything.

Around the same time, I started antagonizing my NMDA receptors to prevent the excitotoxicity effects of excessive glutamate activation. This turned out to be extremely helpful at reducing social anxiety.  The shift in my worldview that came along with overcoming that illness, reminded me very much of the first time I put on glasses. It was rather shocking to realize how beautiful the world was to normal people. Life was suddenly so much easier. I had tons of spare brain capacity  that I previously devoted to constantly hypothesizing about the infinite reasons that everyone hated me.

Unfortunately, after a few months, I was getting depressed again.  I initially chalked this up to my brain's desire to return to homeostasis producing a negative feedback mechanism reulting in tolerance.  I was rather disappointed.  However, a month or so later, my mood began to improve again. I didn't really understand why that happened. Then, my friend Nyles mentioned something kind of gross regarding the effectiveness of fecal transplantation in those with Crohn's disease. This reminded me of something that I hadn't been tracking. It was the probiotics.

I had stopped taking them because I assumed they didn't really do anything.  Then, I happened to find another bottle of the probiotics in my desk drawer and randomly started taking them again. It turned out that my depressed mood occurred when I was not taking the probiotics.  If QuantiModo had existed at the time, I would have noticed this much sooner.

Regardless, I started doing some research and found out that during your fetal development, you actually had two identical nervous systems.  One of them turns into your central nervous system, which is composed of your brain and spinal cord. The other one develops into your enteric nervous system, which is the one attached to your gastrointestinal tract.  These two systems are connected via the vagus nerve, that runs from your brain stem down to your abdomen. Your gut actually sends far more information to your brain than your brain sends to your gut via this nerve.  This link manifests itself in the visceral sensation of butterflies in your stomach when you're nervous or a churning sensation when stressed.
<h2>Bad Cytokines</h2>
<p dir="ltr">Another interesting discovery was that a biological drug, which was prescribed by my doctor for psoriasis, actually reduced my depression.  In many cases, depression is related to inflammation in the brain. Depressed people have elevated levels of inflammatory proteins, or cytokines, such as IL-6 and TNF-alpha. The amino acid tryptophan is a precursor to the neurotransmitter serotonin. Tryptophan is also the precursor to another, far less popular neurotransmitter, <a href="http://www.cnsspectrums.com/userdocs/articleimages/116/HannestadF1big.jpg" target="_blank">kynurenic</a>. When the inflammatory cascade is activated, more tryptophan is made into lame kynurenic, which leaves less tryptophan around to make into groovy serotonin. Humira, the biological psoriasis treatment that I received called blocked these inflammatory cytokines, allowing more tryptophan to be made into serotonin.</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[Happiness does not correlate with health, wealth, education or status. But it does correlate with many small things we can now do in our everyday lives.]]></excerpt:encoded>
